It is concerned with matter and energy at all levels—from the most fundamental particles of matter to the entire universe. Physics can help you understand just about everything in the world around you. That’s because everything around you is matter and has energy. Vocabulary physics: Study of energy and how it interacts with matter.
subject: Scope of Physics
spanish_translation: Resumen La física es la ciencia que estudia la energía, la materia y sus interacciones. Se ocupa de la materia y la energía en todos los niveles, abarcando desde las partículas más fundamentales hasta el universo en su totalidad. La física puede proporcionarte un entendimiento sobre prácticamente todo lo que te rodea, ya que todo en tu entorno está compuesto de materia y posee energía. Vocabulario física: Estudio de la energía y sus interacciones con la materia.

NGSS_matched_standards.description: Plan an investigation to determine the relationships among the energy transferred, the type of matter, the mass, and the change in the average kinetic energy of the particles as measured by the temperature of the sample.
Develop a model that predicts and describes changes in particle motion, temperature, and state of a pure substance when thermal energy is added or removed.
Analyze and interpret data on the properties of substances before and after the substances interact to determine if a chemical reaction has occurred.
Conduct an investigation and evaluate the experimental design to provide evidence that fields exist between objects exerting forces on each other even though the objects are not in contact.
Use mathematical representations to describe a simple model for waves that includes how the amplitude of a wave is related to the energy in a wave.

english_text: Baby steps in science occur as small bits of evidence gradually accumulate. The accumulating evidence lets scientists reﬁne and expand on earlier ideas. For example, the scientiﬁc idea of the atom was introduced in the early 1800s. But scientists came to understand the structure of the atom only as evidence accumulated over the next two centuries. Their understanding of atomic structure continues to expand today.
subject: Nature of Science
spanish_translation: Los primeros pasos en ciencia son pequeños. Se dan cuando la evidencia se acumula poco a poco. La evidencia acumulada deja que los científicos mejoren ideas anteriores. Por ejemplo, la idea del átomo es de los años 1800. Pero los científicos entienden su estructura con más evidencia. Hoy en día, siguen entendiendo mejor el átomo.

NGSS_matched_standards.description: Construct a scientific explanation based on evidence from rock strata for how the geologic time scale is used to organize Earth's 4.6-billion-year-old history.
Construct an explanation based on evidence for how geoscience processes have changed Earth's surface at varying time and spatial scales.
Apply scientific ideas to construct an explanation for the anatomical similarities and differences among modern organisms and between modern and fossil organisms to infer evolutionary relationships.
Construct a scientific explanation based on evidence for how environmental and genetic factors influence the growth of organisms.
Construct a scientific explanation based on evidence for how the uneven distributions of Earth's mineral, energy, and groundwater resources are the result of past and current geoscience processes.

english_text: C.V. Raman (1888–1970) C.V. Raman was an Indian scientist who won the 1930 Nobel prize for physics. He made important discoveries about how light travels through transparent materials. He was also made a knight of the British Empire for his work.
subject: Women and People of Color
spanish_translation: C.V. Raman (1888–1970) C.V. Raman fue un científico de la India. Ganó el premio Nobel de física en 1930. Él descubrió cómo la luz pasa por cosas claras. También fue nombrado caballero por su trabajo.

NGSS_matched_standards.description: Apply scientific principles to design, construct, and test a device that either minimizes or maximizes thermal energy transfer.
Develop and use a model to describe that waves are reflected, absorbed, or transmitted through various materials.
Undertake a design project to construct, test, and modify a device that either releases or absorbs thermal energy by chemical processes.
Develop a model that predicts and describes changes in particle motion, temperature, and state of a pure substance when thermal energy is added or removed.
Construct, use, and present arguments to support the claim that when the kinetic energy of an object changes, energy is transferred to or from the object.

english_text: C.V. Raman (1888–1970) C.V. Raman was an Indian scientist who won the 1930 Nobel prize for physics. He made important discoveries about how light travels through transparent materials. He was also made a knight of the British Empire for his work.
subject: Women and People of Color
spanish_translation: C.V. Raman (1888-1970) C.V. Raman fue un destacado científico indio que obtuvo el Premio Nobel de Física en 1930. Realizó descubrimientos significativos sobre la dispersión de la luz en materiales transparentes, un fenómeno que lleva su nombre: el efecto Raman. Además, fue nombrado caballero del Imperio Británico en reconocimiento a sus contribuciones al campo de la ciencia.

NGSS_matched_standards.description: Apply scientific principles to design, construct, and test a device that either minimizes or maximizes thermal energy transfer.
Develop and use a model to describe that waves are reflected, absorbed, or transmitted through various materials.
Undertake a design project to construct, test, and modify a device that either releases or absorbs thermal energy by chemical processes.
Develop a model that predicts and describes changes in particle motion, temperature, and state of a pure substance when thermal energy is added or removed.
Construct, use, and present arguments to support the claim that when the kinetic energy of an object changes, energy is transferred to or from the object.

english_text: For example, what is the best shape for gathering the sun’s rays? How will sunlight be converted to useable energy to run the car? Will a back-up energy source be needed? After researching the answers, possible designs are developed. This generally takes imagination as well as sound reasoning. Then a model must be designed and tested. This allows any problems with the design to be worked out before a ﬁnal design is selected and produced.
subject: Technological Design Process
spanish_translation: Por ejemplo, ¿cuál es la forma más eficaz para captar los rayos del sol? ¿Cómo se transformará la luz solar en energía utilizable para propulsar el automóvil? ¿Será necesaria una fuente de energía auxiliar? Tras investigar las respuestas, se desarrollan diseños potenciales. Este proceso requiere tanto imaginación como un razonamiento lógico sólido. A continuación, se debe diseñar y probar un prototipo. Esto permite identificar y resolver cualquier problema en el diseño antes de seleccionar y producir el diseño final.

NGSS_matched_standards.description: Define the criteria and constraints of a design problem with sufficient precision to ensure a successful solution, taking into account relevant scientific principles and potential impacts on people and the natural environment that may limit possible solutions.
Undertake a design project to construct, test, and modify a device that either releases or absorbs thermal energy by chemical processes.
Apply scientific principles to design, construct, and test a device that either minimizes or maximizes thermal energy transfer.
Evaluate competing design solutions using a systematic process to determine how well they meet the criteria and constraints of the problem.

Analyze data from tests to determine similarities and differences among several design solutions to identify the best characteristics of each that can be combined into a new solution to better meet the criteria for success.

english_text: A Scientiﬁc Hypothesis Must Be Falsiﬁable A hypothesis may be testable, but even that isn’t enough for it to be a scientiﬁc hypothesis. In addition, it must be possible to show that the hypothesis is false if it really is false. Consider this statement: “There are other planets in the universe where life exists.” This statement is testable. If it is true, it is at least theoretically possible to ﬁnd evidence showing that it’s true.
subject: Hypothesis
spanish_translation: Una hipótesis científica debe poder demostrarse falsa. Una hipótesis se puede comprobar, pero eso no basta. También se debe poder mostrar que no es cierta si es falsa. Mira este ejemplo: “Existen planetas con vida en el universo.” Podemos comprobar esta idea. Si es verdad, teóricamente podríamos encontrar evidencia.

NGSS_matched_standards.description: Use argument based on empirical evidence and scientific reasoning to support an explanation for how characteristic animal behaviors and specialized plant structures affect the probability of successful reproduction of animals and plants respectively.
Conduct an investigation to provide evidence that living things are made of cells; either one cell or many different numbers and types of cells.
Construct a scientific explanation based on evidence for how environmental and genetic factors influence the growth of organisms.
Apply scientific ideas to construct an explanation for the anatomical similarities and differences among modern organisms and between modern and fossil organisms to infer evolutionary relationships.
Integrate qualitative scientific and technical information to support the claim that digitized signals are a more reliable way to encode and transmit information than analog signals.

english_text: Line graphs are especially useful for showing changes over time, or time trends in data, such as how the average number of tornadoes varies throughout the year. Therefore, a line graph would be a good choice to display the data in the Table 1.8. The line graph in the Figure 1.41 shows one way this could be done. Q: Based on the line graph above, describe the trend in tornado numbers by month throughout the course of a year. A: The number of tornadoes rises rapidly from a low in January to a peak in April. This is followed by a relatively slow decline throughout the rest of the year.
subject: Scientiﬁc Graphing
spanish_translation: Los gráficos de líneas son especialmente útiles para representar cambios a lo largo del tiempo, o tendencias temporales en los datos, como la forma en que el número promedio de tornados varía a lo largo del año. Por ende, un gráfico de líneas sería una opción adecuada para presentar los datos de la Tabla 1.8. El gráfico de líneas en la Figura 1.41 ilustra una manera de hacerlo. Pregunta: Basándote en el gráfico de líneas anterior, describe la tendencia en el número de tornados por mes a lo largo del año. Respuesta: El número de tornados aumenta rápidamente desde un nivel bajo en enero hasta alcanzar un pico en abril. A esto le sigue un descenso relativamente lento durante el resto del año.

NGSS_matched_standards.description: Collect data to provide evidence for how the motions and complex interactions of air masses result in changes in weather conditions.
Construct and interpret graphical displays of data to describe the relationships of kinetic energy to the mass of an object and to the speed of an object.
Analyze and interpret data on natural hazards to forecast future catastrophic events and inform the development of technologies to mitigate their effects.

Analyze and interpret data for patterns in the fossil record that document the existence, diversity, extinction, and change of life forms throughout the history of life on Earth under the assumption that natural laws operate today as in the past.
Use mathematical representations to support explanations of how natural selection may lead to increases and decreases of specific traits in populations over time.

english_text: Q: What do you think is the most ethical decision about the Paciﬁc yew? Should the bark be used to make the drug and possibly save human lives? Or should this be prohibited in order to protect the tree from possible extinction? A: This is tough ethical dilemma, and there is no right or wrong answer. Ethical dilemmas such as this often spur scientists to come up with new solutions to problems. That’s what happened in the case of the Paciﬁc yew. Scientists tackled and solved the problem of determining the chemical structure of the anti-cancer drug so it could be synthesized in labs. This is a win-win solution to the problem. The synthetic drug is now available to save lives, and the trees are no longer endangered by being stripped of their bark.
subject: Ethics in Science
spanish_translation: P: ¿Qué crees que es mejor para el tejo del Pacífico? ¿Usar la corteza para hacer medicina y salvar vidas? ¿O evitar que el árbol se pierda? R: Es una decisión difícil. No hay una respuesta buena o mala. Estos problemas hacen que los expertos piensen en nuevas ideas. Eso pasó con el tejo del Pacífico. Aprendieron a hacer la medicina en laboratorios. Así, la medicina salva vidas y los árboles no se dañan.

NGSS_matched_standards.description: Gather and make sense of information to describe that synthetic materials come from natural resources and impact society.

Use argument based on empirical evidence and scientific reasoning to support an explanation for how characteristic animal behaviors and specialized plant structures affect the probability of successful reproduction of animals and plants respectively.
Evaluate competing design solutions for maintaining biodiversity and ecosystem services.
Gather and synthesize information about technologies that have changed the way humans influence the inheritance of desired traits in organisms.

Develop and use a model to describe why structural changes to genes (mutations) located on chromosomes may affect proteins and may result in harmful, beneficial, or neutral effects to the structure and function of the organism.

english_text: Q: If you were to hit four golf balls toward a hole and your shots were both accurate and precise, where would the balls land? A: All four golf balls would land in the hole (accurate) and also very close to one another (precise). Summary Accuracy means making measurements that are close to the true value.
subject: Accuracy and Precision
spanish_translation: P: Si golpeas cuatro pelotas de golf hacia un hoyo y tus tiros son tanto precisos como exactos, ¿dónde aterrizarían las pelotas? R: Las cuatro pelotas de golf caerían dentro del hoyo (exactitud) y además estarían ubicadas muy cerca unas de otras (precisión). Resumen: La exactitud se refiere a realizar mediciones que se aproximan al valor verdadero, mientras que la precisión implica la consistencia y proximidad entre múltiples mediciones o intentos.

NGSS_matched_standards.description: Plan an investigation to provide evidence that the change in an object’s motion depends on the sum of the forces on the object and the mass of the object.
Conduct an investigation and evaluate the experimental design to provide evidence that fields exist between objects exerting forces on each other even though the objects are not in contact.

Define the criteria and constraints of a design problem with sufficient precision to ensure a successful solution, taking into account relevant scientific principles and potential impacts on people and the natural environment that may limit possible solutions.
Apply Newton’s Third Law to design a solution to a problem involving the motion of two colliding objects.
Develop a model to describe that when the arrangement of objects interacting at a distance changes, different amounts of potential energy are stored in the system.

english_text: Q: How do you think physics explains the distorted images formed by a funhouse mirror? A: Physics explains how energy interacts with matter. In this case, for example, physics explains how visible light reﬂects from mirrors to form images. Most mirrors, such as bathroom mirrors, have a ﬂat surface. Light reﬂected from a ﬂat mirror forms an image that looks the same as the object in front of it. Funhouse mirrors, like the one pictured above, are different. They have a curved surface that reﬂects light at different angles. This explains why the images they form are distorted.
subject: Scope of Physics
spanish_translation: P: ¿Cómo crees que la física explica las imágenes extrañas de un espejo de casa de la risa? R: La física nos dice cómo la energía trabaja con la materia. Aquí, explica cómo la luz visible rebota en los espejos. Así se crean las imágenes. La mayoría de los espejos, como los del baño, son planos. La luz que rebota en un espejo plano crea una imagen igual al objeto. Los espejos de casa de la risa son diferentes. Tienen una forma curva. La luz rebota en ángulos distintos. Por eso las imágenes se ven raras.

NGSS_matched_standards.description: Develop and use a model to describe that waves are reflected, absorbed, or transmitted through various materials.
Construct a scientific explanation based on evidence for how the uneven distributions of Earth's mineral, energy, and groundwater resources are the result of past and current geoscience processes.
Use mathematical representations to describe a simple model for waves that includes how the amplitude of a wave is related to the energy in a wave.
Develop a model to describe how food is rearranged through chemical reactions forming new molecules that support growth and/or release energy as this matter moves through an organism.
Construct a scientific explanation based on evidence for the role of photosynthesis in the cycling of matter and flow of energy into and out of organisms.

english_text: Bar Graphs The data in Table 1.6 shows the average number of tornadoes per year for the ten U.S. cities that have the most tornadoes. The data were averaged over the time period 1950–2007. Bar graphs are especially useful for comparing values for different things, such as the average numbers of tornadoes for different cities. Therefore, a bar graph is a good choice for displaying the data in theTable 1.6. The bar graph in Figure 1.39 shows one way that these data could be presented.
subject: Scientiﬁc Graphing
spanish_translation: Gráficas de barras Los datos en la Tabla 1.6 muestran el número promedio de tornados por año en las diez ciudades de EE. UU. que tienen más tornados. Los datos fueron promediados durante el período de tiempo de 1950-2007. Las gráficas de barras son especialmente útiles para comparar valores de diferentes cosas, como el número promedio de tornados para diferentes ciudades. Por lo tanto, una gráfica de barras es una buena opción para mostrar los datos en la Tabla 1.6. La gráfica de barras en la Figura 1.39 muestra una forma en que estos datos podrían presentarse.

NGSS_matched_standards.description: Collect data to provide evidence for how the motions and complex interactions of air masses result in changes in weather conditions.
Construct and interpret graphical displays of data to describe the relationships of kinetic energy to the mass of an object and to the speed of an object.
Analyze and interpret data on natural hazards to forecast future catastrophic events and inform the development of technologies to mitigate their effects.

Analyze and interpret data for patterns in the fossil record that document the existence, diversity, extinction, and change of life forms throughout the history of life on Earth under the assumption that natural laws operate today as in the past.
Develop and use a model to describe how unequal heating and rotation of the Earth cause patterns of atmospheric and oceanic circulation that determine regional climates.

english_text: Laws vs. Theories Scientiﬁc laws state what always happen. This can be very useful. It can let you let you predict what will happen under certain circumstances. For example, Newton’s third law tells you that the harder you hit a softball with a bat, the faster and farther the ball will travel away from the bat. However, scientiﬁc laws have a basic limitation. They don’t explain why things happen. “Why” questions are answered by scientiﬁc theories, not scientiﬁc laws.
subject: Scientiﬁc Law
spanish_translation: Leyes vs. Teorías Las leyes científicas describen lo que siempre ocurre en la naturaleza. Esto es muy útil porque te permite predecir qué sucederá en determinadas circunstancias. Por ejemplo, la tercera ley de Newton establece que cuanto más fuerte golpees una pelota de softbol con un bate, más rápido y más lejos viajará la pelota desde el bate. Sin embargo, las leyes científicas tienen una limitación fundamental: no explican por qué ocurren los fenómenos. Las preguntas sobre el 'por qué' son respondidas por teorías científicas, no por leyes científicas.

NGSS_matched_standards.description: Construct a scientific explanation based on evidence for how environmental and genetic factors influence the growth of organisms.
Apply Newton’s Third Law to design a solution to a problem involving the motion of two colliding objects.
Construct, use, and present arguments to support the claim that when the kinetic energy of an object changes, energy is transferred to or from the object.

Use argument based on empirical evidence and scientific reasoning to support an explanation for how characteristic animal behaviors and specialized plant structures affect the probability of successful reproduction of animals and plants respectively.
Conduct an investigation and evaluate the experimental design to provide evidence that fields exist between objects exerting forces on each other even though the objects are not in contact.

english_text: A Scientiﬁc Hypothesis Must Be Falsiﬁable A hypothesis may be testable, but even that isn’t enough for it to be a scientiﬁc hypothesis. In addition, it must be possible to show that the hypothesis is false if it really is false. Consider this statement: “There are other planets in the universe where life exists.” This statement is testable. If it is true, it is at least theoretically possible to ﬁnd evidence showing that it’s true.
subject: Hypothesis
spanish_translation: Una hipótesis es algo que podemos probar. Debe mostrar si es falsa o verdadera. Por ejemplo: “En otros planetas hay vida”. Podemos buscar pruebas de esto. Esto es porque podemos probar si es cierto.

NGSS_matched_standards.description: Use argument based on empirical evidence and scientific reasoning to support an explanation for how characteristic animal behaviors and specialized plant structures affect the probability of successful reproduction of animals and plants respectively.
Conduct an investigation to provide evidence that living things are made of cells; either one cell or many different numbers and types of cells.
Construct a scientific explanation based on evidence for how environmental and genetic factors influence the growth of organisms.
Apply scientific ideas to construct an explanation for the anatomical similarities and differences among modern organisms and between modern and fossil organisms to infer evolutionary relationships.
Integrate qualitative scientific and technical information to support the claim that digitized signals are a more reliable way to encode and transmit information than analog signals.

english_text: Q: It’s not just athletes that depend on physical science. We all do. What might be some ways that physical science inﬂuences our lives? A: We depend on physical science for just about everything that makes modern life possible. You couldn’t turn on a light, make a phone call, or use a computer without centuries of discoveries in chemistry and physics. The Figure 1.10 show a variety of other ways that people depend on physical science. Think about how knowledge of energy and matter makes each action possible.
subject: Scope of Physical Science
spanish_translation: P: No solo los deportistas dependen de la ciencia física. Todos lo hacemos. ¿De qué maneras podría influir la ciencia física en nuestras vidas? R: Dependemos de la ciencia física para prácticamente todo lo que hace posible la vida moderna. No podrías encender una luz, realizar una llamada telefónica, o utilizar una computadora sin siglos de descubrimientos en campos como la química y la física. La Figura 1.10 ilustra una variedad de otros modos en los que la gente depende de la ciencia física. Reflexiona sobre cómo el conocimiento de la energía y la materia facilita cada acción.

NGSS_matched_standards.description: Conduct an investigation and evaluate the experimental design to provide evidence that fields exist between objects exerting forces on each other even though the objects are not in contact.
Apply scientific principles to design a method for monitoring and minimizing a human impact on the environment.
Construct a scientific explanation based on evidence for how the uneven distributions of Earth's mineral, energy, and groundwater resources are the result of past and current geoscience processes.
Apply scientific ideas to construct an explanation for the anatomical similarities and differences among modern organisms and between modern and fossil organisms to infer evolutionary relationships.
Gather and synthesize information about technologies that have changed the way humans influence the inheritance of desired traits in organisms.

english_text: For example, what is the best shape for gathering the sun’s rays? How will sunlight be converted to useable energy to run the car? Will a back-up energy source be needed? After researching the answers, possible designs are developed. This generally takes imagination as well as sound reasoning. Then a model must be designed and tested. This allows any problems with the design to be worked out before a ﬁnal design is selected and produced.
subject: Technological Design Process
spanish_translation: Por ejemplo, ¿cuál es la mejor forma para captar los rayos del sol? ¿Cómo convertiremos la luz solar en energía que se puede usar para que el coche ande? ¿Necesitaremos otra fuente de energía? Después de investigar, se crean diseños posibles. Esto requiere imaginación y buen razonamiento. Luego, se diseña y prueba un modelo. Esto ayuda a encontrar problemas antes de elegir y fabricar el diseño final.

NGSS_matched_standards.description: Define the criteria and constraints of a design problem with sufficient precision to ensure a successful solution, taking into account relevant scientific principles and potential impacts on people and the natural environment that may limit possible solutions.
Undertake a design project to construct, test, and modify a device that either releases or absorbs thermal energy by chemical processes.
Apply scientific principles to design, construct, and test a device that either minimizes or maximizes thermal energy transfer.
Evaluate competing design solutions using a systematic process to determine how well they meet the criteria and constraints of the problem.

Analyze data from tests to determine similarities and differences among several design solutions to identify the best characteristics of each that can be combined into a new solution to better meet the criteria for success.

english_text: Chloroplasts: A typical plant cell contains green structures, called chloroplasts, in the cytoplasm. A chloroplast, shown in Figure 5, captures energy from sunlight and changes it to a form of energy cells can use in making food. Animal cells don’t have chloroplasts, but the cells of plants and some other organisms do. Chloroplasts make leaves green because leaf cells contain many chloroplasts.
subject: Looking Inside Cells
spanish_translation: Cloroplastos: Una célula vegetal tiene estructuras verdes llamadas cloroplastos. Un cloroplasto toma energía del sol y la cambia a energía que las células pueden usar para hacer comida. Las células animales no tienen cloroplastos. Pero las células de las plantas y algunos otros organismos sí los tienen. Los cloroplastos hacen que las hojas sean verdes porque hay muchos cloroplastos en las células de las hojas.

NGSS_matched_standards.description: Construct a scientific explanation based on evidence for the role of photosynthesis in the cycling of matter and flow of energy into and out of organisms.
Conduct an investigation to provide evidence that living things are made of cells; either one cell or many different numbers and types of cells.

Use argument based on empirical evidence and scientific reasoning to support an explanation for how characteristic animal behaviors and specialized plant structures affect the probability of successful reproduction of animals and plants respectively.
Develop and use a model to describe the function of a cell as a whole and ways the parts of cells contribute to the function.
Develop a model to describe the cycling of matter and flow of energy among living and nonliving parts of an ecosystem.

english_text: Q: What is the maximum mass this triple beam balance can measure? A: The maximum mass it can measure is 610 grams (500 grams + 100 grams + 10 grams). Q: What is the smallest mass this triple beam balance can measure? A: The smallest mass it can measure is one-tenth (0.1) of a gram. To measure very small masses, scientists use electronic balances, like the one in the Figure 1.31. This type of balance also makes it easier to make accurate measurements because mass is shown as a digital readout. In the picture below, the balance is being used to measure the mass of a yellow powder on a glass dish. The mass of the dish alone would have to be measured ﬁrst and then subtracted from the mass of the dish and powder together. The difference between the two masses is the mass of the powder alone.
subject: Scientiﬁc Measuring Devices
spanish_translation: Q: ¿Cuál es la masa máxima que esta balanza puede medir? A: La masa máxima es de 610 gramos. Q: ¿Cuál es la masa más pequeña que esta balanza puede medir? A: La masa más pequeña es 0.1 gramos. Para medir masas pequeñas, los científicos usan balanzas electrónicas. Este tipo de balanza muestra la masa en un número digital. En la imagen, se mide un polvo amarillo en un plato. Primero, mida la masa del plato solo. Luego reste eso de la masa con el polvo. La diferencia es la masa del polvo.

NGSS_matched_standards.description: Plan an investigation to determine the relationships among the energy transferred, the type of matter, the mass, and the change in the average kinetic energy of the particles as measured by the temperature of the sample.
Analyze and interpret data to determine scale properties of objects in the solar system.
Develop and use a model to describe how the total number of atoms does not change in a chemical reaction and thus mass is conserved.
Plan an investigation to provide evidence that the change in an object’s motion depends on the sum of the forces on the object and the mass of the object.
Apply Newton’s Third Law to design a solution to a problem involving the motion of two colliding objects.

english_text: Measuring Length with a Metric Ruler You’ve probably been using a ruler to measure length since you were in elementary school. But you may have made most of the measurements in English units of length, such as inches and feet. In science, length is most often measured in SI units, such as millimeters and centimeters. Many rulers have both types of units, one on each edge. The ruler pictured below has only SI units. It is shown here bigger than it really is so it’s easier to see the small lines, which measure millimeters. The large lines and numbers stand for centimeters. Count the number of small lines from the left end of the ruler (0.0). You should count 10 lines because there are 10 millimeters in a centimeter.
subject: Scientiﬁc Measuring Devices
spanish_translation: Midiendo Longitud con una Regla Métrica Es probable que hayas estado usando una regla para medir longitudes desde la escuela primaria. Sin embargo, es posible que la mayoría de estas mediciones las hayas realizado en unidades inglesas, como pulgadas y pies. En el ámbito científico, la longitud generalmente se mide en unidades del Sistema Internacional (SI), como milímetros y centímetros. Muchas reglas presentan ambos tipos de unidades, una en cada borde. La regla ilustrada abajo presenta únicamente unidades del SI. Se muestra aquí ampliada para facilitar la visualización de las subdivisiones pequeñas, que representan milímetros. Las líneas más largas y los números indican los centímetros. Si cuentas el número de líneas pequeñas desde el extremo izquierdo de la regla (0.0), deberías contar 10 líneas ya que hay 10 milímetros en un centímetro. Esta precisión es vital para llevar a cabo mediciones exactas en experimentos científicos.

NGSS_matched_standards.description: Analyze and interpret data to determine scale properties of objects in the solar system.
Construct a scientific explanation based on evidence from rock strata for how the geologic time scale is used to organize Earth's 4.6-billion-year-old history.
Integrate qualitative scientific and technical information to support the claim that digitized signals are a more reliable way to encode and transmit information than analog signals.
Construct an explanation based on evidence for how geoscience processes have changed Earth's surface at varying time and spatial scales.

Define the criteria and constraints of a design problem with sufficient precision to ensure a successful solution, taking into account relevant scientific principles and potential impacts on people and the natural environment that may limit possible solutions.

english_text: Using Scientiﬁc Notation It’s easier to convert numbers to and from scientiﬁc notation than you might think. Refer to the examples on the chalkboard below as you read the following steps. Follow the steps in the sequence listed here to convert a number to scientiﬁc notation. Follow the steps in the reverse order to convert a number from scientiﬁc notation. 1. Move the decimal point left or right until you reach the last nonzero digit. This new decimal number is a in a × 10b. 2. Count how many places you moved the decimal point in Step 1. This number is b in a × 10b. 3. Did you move the decimal point left (ﬁrst example in the Figure 1.38)? If so, b is positive. Did you move the decimal point right (second example in the Figure 1.38)? If so, b is negative.
subject: Scientiﬁc Notation
spanish_translation: Usando la notación científica Es más fácil convertir números a y desde la notación científica de lo que piensas. Consulta los ejemplos en el pizarrón a medida que lees los siguientes pasos. Sigue los pasos en el orden que se detalla aquí para convertir un número a notación científica. Sigue los pasos en orden inverso para convertir un número desde notación científica. 1. Mueve el punto decimal hacia la izquierda o la derecha hasta que llegues al último dígito distinto de cero. Este nuevo número decimal es a en a × 10b. 2. Cuenta cuántos lugares moviste el punto decimal en el Paso 1. Este número es b en a × 10b. 3. ¿Moviste el punto decimal hacia la izquierda (primer ejemplo en la Figura 1.38)? Si es así, b es positivo. ¿Moviste el punto decimal hacia la derecha (segundo ejemplo en la Figura 1.38)? Si es así, b es negativo.

NGSS_matched_standards.description: Construct and interpret graphical displays of data to describe the relationships of kinetic energy to the mass of an object and to the speed of an object.
Integrate qualitative scientific and technical information to support the claim that digitized signals are a more reliable way to encode and transmit information than analog signals.
Analyze and interpret data to determine scale properties of objects in the solar system.
Develop a model to describe that when the arrangement of objects interacting at a distance changes, different amounts of potential energy are stored in the system.

Plan an investigation to determine the relationships among the energy transferred, the type of matter, the mass, and the change in the average kinetic energy of the particles as measured by the temperature of the sample.

english_text: Physics in the World Around You Physics can help you understand just about everything in the world around you. That’s because everything around you consists of matter and energy. Several examples of matter and energy interacting are pictured in the Figure 1.12. Q: Based on the examples above, what might be other examples of energy and matter interacting? A: Like the strings of cello, anything that vibrates produces waves of energy that travel through matter. For example, when you throw a pebble into a pond, waves of energy travel from the pebble through the water in all directions. Like an incandescent light bulb, anything that glows consists of matter that produces light energy. For example, ﬁreﬂies use chemicals to produce light energy. Like a moving tennis racket, anything that moves has energy because it is moving, including your eyes as they read this sentence.
subject: Scope of Physics
spanish_translation: La física en el mundo que te rodea. La física te ayuda a entender casi todo. Esto es porque todo está hecho de materia y energía. Varios ejemplos se muestran en la Figura 1.12. P: ¿Cuáles son otros ejemplos de energía y materia unidas? R: Como las cuerdas de un instrumento musical, cualquier cosa que vibre manda ondas. Por ejemplo, al lanzar una piedrita en un estanque, ondas van en todas direcciones. Como una luz brillante, todo lo que brilla tiene materia que produce energía de luz. Por ejemplo, las luciérnagas usan materiales especiales para hacer luz. Como una raqueta de tenis en movimiento, todo lo que se mueve tiene energía, igual que tus ojos al leer esto.

NGSS_matched_standards.description: Construct a scientific explanation based on evidence for the role of photosynthesis in the cycling of matter and flow of energy into and out of organisms.
Construct, use, and present arguments to support the claim that when the kinetic energy of an object changes, energy is transferred to or from the object.
Develop a model to describe how food is rearranged through chemical reactions forming new molecules that support growth and/or release energy as this matter moves through an organism.
Develop a model to describe the cycling of matter and flow of energy among living and nonliving parts of an ecosystem.
Construct and present arguments using evidence to support the claim that gravitational interactions are attractive and depend on the masses of interacting objects.

english_text: Using Scientiﬁc Notation It’s easier to convert numbers to and from scientiﬁc notation than you might think. Refer to the examples on the chalkboard below as you read the following steps. Follow the steps in the sequence listed here to convert a number to scientiﬁc notation. Follow the steps in the reverse order to convert a number from scientiﬁc notation. 1. Move the decimal point left or right until you reach the last nonzero digit. This new decimal number is a in a × 10b. 2. Count how many places you moved the decimal point in Step 1. This number is b in a × 10b. 3. Did you move the decimal point left (ﬁrst example in the Figure 1.38)? If so, b is positive. Did you move the decimal point right (second example in the Figure 1.38)? If so, b is negative.
subject: Scientiﬁc Notation
spanish_translation: Uso de la Notación Científica Cambiar números a notación científica es fácil. Mira los ejemplos en el pizarrón mientras lees. Sigue los pasos como se muestra. Para cambiar un número, sigue estos pasos. Haz lo contrario para volverlo normal. 1. Mueve el punto hasta el último número no cero. Este nuevo número es a en a × 10^b. 2. Cuenta los espacios que moviste el punto. Ese número es b en a × 10^b. 3. ¿Moviste el punto a la izquierda? Entonces b es positivo. ¿Moviste el punto a la derecha? Entonces b es negativo.

NGSS_matched_standards.description: Construct and interpret graphical displays of data to describe the relationships of kinetic energy to the mass of an object and to the speed of an object.
Integrate qualitative scientific and technical information to support the claim that digitized signals are a more reliable way to encode and transmit information than analog signals.

english_text: Passive Transport Every living cell exists in a liquid environment. One of the most important processes carried out by the cell membrane is to keep a cell in homeostasis. Homeostasis is a state of relatively constant internal physical and chemical conditions. It does this by regulating the movement of molecules and other substances from one side of the membrane to the other side.
subject: Cell Transport
spanish_translation: Transporte pasivo Cada célula viva existe en un entorno líquido. Uno de los procesos más importantes que realiza la membrana celular es mantener la célula en homeostasis. La homeostasis es un estado de condiciones físicas y químicas internas relativamente constantes. Lo logra regulando el movimiento de moléculas y otras sustancias de un lado a otro de la membrana.

NGSS_matched_standards.description: Use a model to illustrate that cellular respiration is a chemical process whereby the bonds of food molecules and oxygen molecules are broken and the bonds in new compounds are formed, resulting in a net transfer of energy.
Develop and use a model to illustrate the hierarchical organization of interacting systems that provide specific functions within multicellular organisms.
Use a model to illustrate the role of cellular division (mitosis) and differentiation in producing and maintaining complex organisms.
Construct and revise an explanation based on evidence for the cycling of matter and flow of energy in aerobic and anaerobic conditions.
Use mathematical representations to support claims for the cycling of matter and flow of energy among organisms in an ecosystem.

english_text: Sorting: The tendency for currents of air or water to separate sediments according to size is called sorting. Sediments can be very well sorted, very poorly sorted, or somewhere in between, as shown in Figure 4. In well-sorted sediments, all of the grains are roughly the same size and shape. Poorly sorted sediment consists of grains that are many different sizes. The sorting of a sediment is the result of changes in the speed of the agent that is moving the sediment. For example, when a fast-moving stream enters a lake, the speed of the water decreases sharply. Because large grains are too heavy for the current to carry, these grains are deposited first. Fine grains can stay suspended in the water for much longer than large grains can. So, fine particles are commonly deposited farther from shore or on top of coarser sediments.
subject: Rocks
spanish_translation: Clasificación: La tendencia de las corrientes de aire o agua a separar los sedimentos según su tamaño se llama clasificación. Los sedimentos pueden estar muy bien clasificados, muy mal clasificados o en algún punto intermedio, como se muestra en la Figura 4. En sedimentos bien clasificados, todos los granos son aproximadamente del mismo tamaño y forma. Los sedimentos mal clasificados consisten en granos de muchos tamaños diferentes. La clasificación de un sedimento es el resultado de los cambios en la velocidad del agente que mueve el sedimento. Por ejemplo, cuando un arroyo de rápido movimiento entra a un lago, la velocidad del agua disminuye abruptamente. Debido a que los granos grandes son demasiado pesados para que la corriente los lleve, estos granos se depositan primero. Los granos finos pueden permanecer suspendidos en el agua durante mucho más tiempo que los granos grandes. Por lo tanto, las partículas finas suelen depositarse más lejos de la orilla o sobre sedimentos más gruesos.

NGSS_matched_standards.description: Develop a model to illustrate how Earth’s internal and surface processes operate at different spatial and temporal scales to form continental and ocean-floor features.
Develop a quantitative model to describe the cycling of carbon among the hydrosphere, atmosphere, geosphere, and biosphere.

Evaluate claims, evidence, and reasoning that the complex interactions in ecosystems maintain relatively consistent numbers and types of organisms in stable conditions, but changing conditions may result in a new ecosystem.
Plan and conduct an investigation of the properties of water and its effects on Earth materials and surface processes.

english_text: Vacuoles and Vesicles: Every factory needs a place to store things, and so does every cell. Many cells contain vacuoles, which are large saclike, membrane-enclosed structures. Vacuoles store materials like water, salts, proteins, and carbohydrates. In many plant cells, there is a single large central vacuole filled with liquid. The pressure of the central vacuole in these cells increases their rigidity, making it possible for plants to support heavy structures, such as leaves and flowers. Figure 8-9 shows a typical plant cell’s central vacuole.
subject: Cell Structure
spanish_translation: Vacuolas y Vesículas: Cada fábrica necesita un lugar para almacenar cosas, y cada célula también. Muchas células contienen vacuolas, que son estructuras sacas grandes, rodeadas por membrana. Las vacuolas almacenan materiales como agua, sales, proteínas y carbohidratos. En muchas células vegetales, hay una sola gran vacuola central llena de líquido. La presión de la vacuola central en estas células aumenta su rigidez, lo que permite a las plantas soportar estructuras pesadas, como hojas y flores. La figura 8-9 muestra la vacuola central típica de una célula vegetal.

NGSS_matched_standards.description: Plan and conduct an investigation to gather evidence to compare the structure of substances at the bulk scale to infer the strength of electrical forces between particles.

Use a model to illustrate that cellular respiration is a chemical process whereby the bonds of food molecules and oxygen molecules are broken and the bonds in new compounds are formed, resulting in a net transfer of energy.
Develop and use a model to illustrate the hierarchical organization of interacting systems that provide specific functions within multicellular organisms.
Construct an explanation based on evidence for how the structure of DNA determines the structure of proteins, which carry out the essential functions of life through systems of specialized cells.
Develop a model to illustrate the role of photosynthesis and cellular respiration in the cycling of carbon among the biosphere, atmosphere, hydrosphere, and geosphere.

english_text: Topographic Map Symbols: Symbols are used to show certain features on topographic maps. Symbol color indicates the type of feature. For example, constructed features, such as buildings, boundaries, roads, and rail-roads, are generally shown in black. Major highways are shown in red. Bodies of water are shown in blue, and forested areas are shown in green. Contour lines are brown or black. Often, areas whose map information has been updated based on aerial photography but not verified by field exploration are shown in purple. A key to common topographic map symbols is provided for your reference in Appendix E.
subject: Models of the Earth
spanish_translation: Símbolos en mapas topográficos: Los símbolos se utilizan para mostrar ciertas características en los mapas topográficos. El color del símbolo indica el tipo de característica. Por ejemplo, las características construidas, como edificios, límites, carreteras y ferrocarriles, generalmente se muestran en negro. Las carreteras principales se muestran en rojo. Los cuerpos de agua se muestran en azul, y las áreas boscosas se muestran en verde. Las líneas de contorno son marrones o negras. A menudo, las áreas cuya información del mapa se ha actualizado con base en la fotografía aérea pero no ha sido verificada por exploración en campo se muestran en morado. Se proporciona una clave de símbolos comunes en los mapas topográficos para su referencia en el Apéndice E.

NGSS_matched_standards.description: Use mathematical representations to support and revise explanations based on evidence about factors affecting biodiversity and populations in ecosystems of different scales.
Use a computational representation to illustrate the relationships among Earth systems and how those relationships are being modified due to human activity.
Develop a model to illustrate how Earth’s internal and surface processes operate at different spatial and temporal scales to form continental and ocean-floor features.
Use mathematical and/or computational representations to support explanations of factors that affect carrying capacity of ecosystems at different scales.

Analyze geoscience data and the results from global climate models to make an evidence-based forecast of the current rate of global or regional climate change and associated future impacts to Earth's systems.

english_text: Light Microscopes: The type of microscope you are probably most familiar with is the compound light microscope. A typical light microscope allows light to pass through a specimen and uses two lenses to form an image. The first lens, called the objective lens, is located just above the specimen. This lens enlarges the image of the specimen. The second lens, called the ocular lens, magnifies this image still further. Unfortunately, light itself limits the detail, or resolution, of images in a microscope. Like all forms of radiation, light waves are diffracted, or scattered, as they pass through matter. Because of this, light microscopes can produce clear images of objects only to a magnification of about 1000 times.
subject: Life is Cellular
spanish_translation: Microscopios de luz: El tipo de microscopio que probablemente conozcas mejor es el microscopio compuesto de luz. Este tipo permite que la luz pase a través de una muestra y usa dos lentes para crear una imagen. La primera lente, llamada lente objetivo, está justo encima de la muestra y la hace parecer más grande. La segunda lente, llamada lente ocular, hace que la imagen sea aún más grande. Sin embargo, la luz misma limita cuán nítida puede ser la imagen en un microscopio. Al igual que otras formas de energía, las ondas de luz se separan cuando pasan por ciertas cosas. Por eso, los microscopios de luz solo pueden mostrar imágenes claras de cosas hasta unas 1000 veces más grandes.

NGSS_matched_standards.description: Apply science and engineering ideas to design, evaluate, and refine a device that minimizes the force on a macroscopic object during a collision.
Use a model to illustrate how photosynthesis transforms light energy into stored chemical energy.
Communicate technical information about how some technological devices use the principles of wave behavior and wave interactions with matter to transmit and capture information and energy.

english_text: Intermediate Rocks: Rocks of the intermediate family are made up of the minerals plagioclase feldspar, hornblende, pyroxene, and biotite mica. Rocks in the intermediate family contain lower proportions of silica than rocks in the felsic family do but contain higher proportions of silica than rocks in the mafic family contain. Rocks in the intermediate family include diorite and andesite.
subject: Rocks
spanish_translation: Las rocas intermedias están hechas de minerales como la sal y el arena, la hornblenda, el fuego y la mica. Contienen menos arena que las rocas muy claras, pero más arena que las rocas oscuras.

english_text: Conic Projections: A projection made by placing a paper cone over a lighted globe so that the axis of the cone aligns with the axis of the globe is known as a conic projection. The cone touches the globe along one parallel of latitude. As shown in Figure 4, areas near the parallel where the cone and globe are in contact are distorted the least.
subject: Models of the Earth
spanish_translation: Las proyecciones en cono son como hacer un mapa de la Tierra. Imagina que colocas un cono sobre un globo y lo alineas con su eje. El cono toca el globo en una línea llamada paralelo. En la figura 4, puedes ver cómo las partes cerca de esta línea están menos retorcidas.

english_text: In multicellular organisms, cells are specialized for specific tasks, such as support, communication, movement, or the production of proteins or other cell products. As a general rule, the cells of multi cellular organisms cannot survive individually. They work together to complete the tasks of life.
subject: Life is Cellular
spanish_translation: En los seres vivos con muchas células, cada una tiene un trabajo especial, como sostener el cuerpo, enviar mensajes, moverse o hacer proteínas. Por lo general, las células solas no pueden vivir. Necesitan trabajar juntas para hacer todo lo que el ser vivo necesita hacer.

NGSS_matched_standards.description: Develop and use a model to illustrate the hierarchical organization of interacting systems that provide specific functions within multicellular organisms.
Use a model to illustrate the role of cellular division (mitosis) and differentiation in producing and maintaining complex organisms.

Evaluate claims, evidence, and reasoning that the complex interactions in ecosystems maintain relatively consistent numbers and types of organisms in stable conditions, but changing conditions may result in a new ecosystem.

english_text: Earthquakes and Society: Movement of the ground during an earthquake seldom directly causes many deaths or injuries. Instead, most injuries result from the collapse of buildings and other structures or from falling objects and flying glass. Other dangers include landslides, fires, explosions caused by broken electric and gas lines, and floodwaters released from collapsing dams. Tsunamis: An earthquake whose epicenter is on the ocean floor may cause a giant ocean wave called a tsunami, which may cause serious destruction if it crashes into land. A tsunami may begin to form when a sudden drop or rise in the ocean floor occurs because of faulting associated with undersea earthquakes. The drop or rise of the ocean floor causes a large mass of sea water to also drop or rise suddenly. This movement sets into motion a series of long, low waves that increase in height as they near the shore. These waves are tsunamis.
subject: Earthquakes
spanish_translation: Los terremotos y la sociedad: El movimiento del suelo durante un terremoto rara vez causa directamente muchas muertes o lesiones. En cambio, la mayoría de las lesiones provienen del colapso de edificios y otras estructuras, o de objetos que caen y vidrio que vuela. Otros peligros incluyen deslizamientos de tierra, incendios, explosiones causadas por líneas eléctricas y de gas rotas, y aguas de inundación liberadas por represas colapsadas. Tsunamis: Un terremoto cuyo epicentro está en el fondo del océano puede causar una enorme ola oceánica llamada tsunami, que puede causar una destrucción seria si impacta en tierra. Un tsunami puede comenzar a formarse cuando ocurre una caída o elevación repentina en el fondo del océano debido a fallas asociadas con terremotos submarinos. La caída o elevación del fondo del océano provoca que una gran masa de agua del mar también caiga o suba repentinamente. Este movimiento pone en marcha una serie de olas largas y bajas que aumentan de altura a medida que se acercan a la costa. Estas olas son los tsunamis.

NGSS_matched_standards.description: Develop a model to illustrate how Earth’s internal and surface processes operate at different spatial and temporal scales to form continental and ocean-floor features.

english_text: Cells are the basic living units of all organisms, but sometimes a single cell actually is the organism. In fact, in terms of their numbers, unicellular organisms dominate life on Earth. This false-color micrograph shows a type of plankton (in blue). Plankton are unicellular marine organisms that do everything you would expect a living thing to do.
subject: Homeostasis and Cells
spanish_translation: Las células son como los pequeños bloques que forman todo en los seres vivos. En el mar, hay organismos muy pequeños llamados plancton (en azul). El plancton son como grupos de células que hacen cosas que los seres vivos hacen.

NGSS_matched_standards.description: Use a model to illustrate the role of cellular division (mitosis) and differentiation in producing and maintaining complex organisms.
Develop and use a model to illustrate the hierarchical organization of interacting systems that provide specific functions within multicellular organisms.

Evaluate claims, evidence, and reasoning that the complex interactions in ecosystems maintain relatively consistent numbers and types of organisms in stable conditions, but changing conditions may result in a new ecosystem.
Construct an explanation based on evidence for how the structure of DNA determines the structure of proteins, which carry out the essential functions of life through systems of specialized cells.
Use mathematical representations to support claims for the cycling of matter and flow of energy among organisms in an ecosystem.

english_text: Lysosomes: Even the neatest, cleanest factory needs a cleanup crew, and that’s where lysosomes come in. Lysosomes are small organelles filled with enzymes. Lysosomes break down lipids, carbohydrates, and proteins into small molecules that can be used by the rest of the cell. They are also involved in breaking down organelles that have outlived their usefulness. Lysosomes per- form the vital function of removing “junk” that might otherwise accumulate and clutter up the cell. A number of rare but serious human diseases can be traced to lysosomes that fail to function properly. Biologists once thought only animal cells contained lysosomes, but it is now clear that a few types of plant cells contain them as well.
subject: Cell Structure
spanish_translation: Lisosomas: Incluso la fábrica más ordenada y limpia necesita un equipo de limpieza, y ahí es donde entran en juego los lisosomas. Los lisosomas son pequeños organelos llenos de enzimas. Descomponen lípidos, carbohidratos y proteínas en moléculas pequeñas que pueden ser utilizadas por el resto de la célula. También participan en la descomposición de organelos que han superado su utilidad. Los lisosomas realizan la función vital de eliminar el «basurero» que de otro modo podría acumularse y desordenar la célula. Varias enfermedades humanas raras pero graves pueden ser atribuidas a lisosomas que no funcionan adecuadamente. Los biólogos pensaron en un momento que solo las células animales contenían lisosomas, pero ahora está claro que algunos tipos de células vegetales también los contienen.

NGSS_matched_standards.description: Use a model to illustrate the role of cellular division (mitosis) and differentiation in producing and maintaining complex organisms.
Construct an explanation based on evidence for how the structure of DNA determines the structure of proteins, which carry out the essential functions of life through systems of specialized cells.
Develop and use a model to illustrate the hierarchical organization of interacting systems that provide specific functions within multicellular organisms.

Use a model to illustrate that cellular respiration is a chemical process whereby the bonds of food molecules and oxygen molecules are broken and the bonds in new compounds are formed, resulting in a net transfer of energy.
Design, evaluate, and refine a solution for reducing the impacts of human activities on the environment and biodiversity.

english_text: Heterogeneous Mixtures: Mixtures in which two or more substances are not uniformly distributed are called heterogeneous mixtures. For example, the igneous rock granite is a heterogeneous mixture of crystals of the minerals quartz, feldspar, hornblende, and biotite. Homogeneous Mixtures: In chemistry, the word homogeneous means “having the same composition and properties throughout.” A homogeneous mixture of two or more substances that are uniformly dispersed through- out the mixture is a solution. solution. Any part of a given sample of the solution known as sea water, for example, will have the same composition. Sodium chloride, NaCl, (along with many other ionic compounds) is dissolved in sea water. The positive ends of water molecules attract negative chloride ions. And the negative ends of water molecules attract positive sodium ions. Eventually, all of the sodium and chloride ions become uniformly distributed among the water molecules. Gases and solids can also be solutions. An alloy is a solution composed of two or more metals. The steel shown in Figure 6 is an example of such a solution, both in liquid and solid states.
subject: Earth Chemistry
spanish_translation: Mezclas Heterogéneas: Las mezclas en las que dos o más sustancias no están distribuidas uniformemente se llaman mezclas heterogéneas. Por ejemplo, el granito es una mezcla heterogénea de cristales de los minerales cuarzo, feldespato, hornblenda y biotita. Mezclas Homogéneas: En química, la palabra homogénea significa “tener la misma composición y propiedades en todo”. Una mezcla homogénea de dos o más sustancias que están distribuidas uniformemente en toda la mezcla es una solución. Por ejemplo, en cualquier parte de una muestra dada de agua de mar, tendrá la misma composición. El cloruro de sodio, NaCl (junto con muchos otros compuestos iónicos) está disuelto en el agua de mar. Los extremos positivos de las moléculas de agua atraen a los iones cloruro negativos. Y los extremos negativos de las moléculas de agua atraen a los iones sodio positivos. Finalmente, todos los iones de sodio y cloruro se distribuyen uniformemente entre las moléculas de agua. Los gases y sólidos también pueden ser soluciones. Una aleación es una solución compuesta de dos o más metales. El acero mostrado en la Figura 6 es un ejemplo de tal solución, tanto en estado líquido como sólido.

NGSS_matched_standards.description: Plan and conduct an investigation of the properties of water and its effects on Earth materials and surface processes.
Develop a model to illustrate how Earth’s internal and surface processes operate at different spatial and temporal scales to form continental and ocean-floor features.

Construct and revise an explanation based on evidence for how carbon, hydrogen, and oxygen from sugar molecules may combine with other elements to form amino acids and/or other large carbon-based molecules.
Use mathematical representations to support the claim that atoms, and therefore mass, are conserved during a chemical reaction.
Refine the design of a chemical system by specifying a change in conditions that would produce increased amounts of products at equilibrium.

english_text: Facilitated Diffusion Since cell membranes are built around lipid bilayers, the molecules that pass through them most easily are small and uncharged. These properties allow them to dissolve in the membrane’s lipid environment. But many charged ions, like Cl−, and large molecules, like the sugar glucose, seem to pass through cell membranes very quickly, as if they have a shortcut
subject: Cell Transport
spanish_translation: Difusión facilitada Dado que las membranas celulares están construidas alrededor de láminas bilipidicas, las moléculas que pasan a través de ellas con más facilidad son pequeñas e impares. Estas propiedades les permiten disolverse en el entorno lipídico de la membrana. Sin embargo, muchos iones cargados, como Cl−, y grandes moléculas, como la glucosa, parecen pasar a través de las membranas celulares muy rápidamente, como si tuvieran un atajo.

NGSS_matched_standards.description: Use a model to illustrate that cellular respiration is a chemical process whereby the bonds of food molecules and oxygen molecules are broken and the bonds in new compounds are formed, resulting in a net transfer of energy.
Develop and use a model to illustrate the hierarchical organization of interacting systems that provide specific functions within multicellular organisms.
Construct and revise an explanation based on evidence for the cycling of matter and flow of energy in aerobic and anaerobic conditions.
Develop a model to illustrate that the release or absorption of energy from a chemical reaction system depends upon the changes in total bond energy.

Construct and revise an explanation based on evidence for how carbon, hydrogen, and oxygen from sugar molecules may combine with other elements to form amino acids and/or other large carbon-based molecules.

english_text: BUILD VOCABULARY: Academic Words The noun transmission means “the process of sending.” This often implies that one thing is being sent through something else. In transmission electron microscopy, a beam of electrons is sent through a thin sample.
subject: Life is Cellular
spanish_translation: ¡EXPLORA LA VIDA AL MÍNIMO! La ciencia nos enseña que 'transmisión' es como 'enviar' algo. En la microscopía electrónica, enviamos un rayo de electrones a través de una muestra muy delgada para verla con gran detalle.

NGSS_matched_standards.description: Communicate technical information about how some technological devices use the principles of wave behavior and wave interactions with matter to transmit and capture information and energy.
Evaluate questions about the advantages of using digital transmission and storage of information.
Communicate scientific ideas about the way stars, over their life cycle, produce elements.
Evaluate the validity and reliability of claims in published materials of the effects that different frequencies of electromagnetic radiation have when absorbed by matter.

Evaluate the claims, evidence, and reasoning behind the idea that electromagnetic radiation can be described either by a wave model or a particle model, and that for some situations one model is more useful than the other.

english_text: In the past decade, new microscopes have been developed that use precise, computer controlled laser beams to scan across samples and gather very high resolution information. These instruments and techniques are making it possible to study living cells at a level of detail never possible before, opening up even more opportunities for research.
subject: Life is Cellular
spanish_translation: Los científicos han creado un instrumento muy especial. Este instrumento puede ver cosas muy pequeñas, como las células, usando un rayo de luz. Así, pueden aprender más sobre cómo son y qué hacen.

NGSS_matched_standards.description: Use a model to illustrate the role of cellular division (mitosis) and differentiation in producing and maintaining complex organisms.
Construct an explanation based on evidence for how the structure of DNA determines the structure of proteins, which carry out the essential functions of life through systems of specialized cells.
Apply science and engineering ideas to design, evaluate, and refine a device that minimizes the force on a macroscopic object during a collision.
Communicate technical information about how some technological devices use the principles of wave behavior and wave interactions with matter to transmit and capture information and energy.
Develop and use a model to illustrate the hierarchical organization of interacting systems that provide specific functions within multicellular organisms.

english_text: In the previous lesson, we compared cell walls and cell membranes to the roof and walls of a factory. When you think about how cells move materials in and out, it might be more helpful to think of a cell as a nation. The boundaries of a nation are its borders, and nearly every nation tries to regulate and control the goods that move across its borders, like the shipping containers seen here entering and leaving a seaport.
subject: Cell Transport
spanish_translation: Las células son como países. Las fronteras son lo que las separa, y los países controlan lo que entra y sale, como los camiones que llevan cosas al puerto.

NGSS_matched_standards.description: Use a model to illustrate the role of cellular division (mitosis) and differentiation in producing and maintaining complex organisms.
Construct an explanation based on evidence for how the structure of DNA determines the structure of proteins, which carry out the essential functions of life through systems of specialized cells.
Develop and use a model to illustrate the hierarchical organization of interacting systems that provide specific functions within multicellular organisms.

Use a model to illustrate that cellular respiration is a chemical process whereby the bonds of food molecules and oxygen molecules are broken and the bonds in new compounds are formed, resulting in a net transfer of energy.
Evaluate or refine a technological solution that reduces impacts of human activities on natural systems.

english_text: Cells are the basic living units of all organisms, but sometimes a single cell actually is the organism. In fact, in terms of their numbers, unicellular organisms dominate life on Earth. This false-color micrograph shows a type of plankton (in blue). Plankton are unicellular marine organisms that do everything you would expect a living thing to do.
subject: Homeostasis and Cells
spanish_translation: Las células son las unidades básicas de vida de todos los organismos, pero a veces una sola célula es en realidad el organismo. De hecho, en términos de cantidad, los organismos unicelulares dominan la vida en la Tierra. Este micrográfico de falso color muestra un tipo de plancton (en azul). Los planctones son organismos marinos unicelulares que hacen todo lo que esperarías de un ser vivo.

NGSS_matched_standards.description: Use a model to illustrate the role of cellular division (mitosis) and differentiation in producing and maintaining complex organisms.
Develop and use a model to illustrate the hierarchical organization of interacting systems that provide specific functions within multicellular organisms.

Evaluate claims, evidence, and reasoning that the complex interactions in ecosystems maintain relatively consistent numbers and types of organisms in stable conditions, but changing conditions may result in a new ecosystem.
Construct an explanation based on evidence for how the structure of DNA determines the structure of proteins, which carry out the essential functions of life through systems of specialized cells.
Use mathematical representations to support claims for the cycling of matter and flow of energy among organisms in an ecosystem.

english_text: Figure 8-17 shows a substance that can cross the cell membrane. Its molecules will tend to move toward the area where it is less concentrated until it is evenly distributed. Equilibrium is reached when the concentration of the substance on both sides of the cell membrane is the same. Even at equilibrium, molecules continue to move across the membrane in both directions. However, there is no further net change in the concentration on either side.
subject: Cell Transport
spanish_translation: La imagen 8-17 muestra una sustancia que puede pasar a través de la pared de la célula. Sus moléculas se mueven hacia donde hay menos, hasta que están bien repartidas. Se alcanza la igualdad cuando la sustancia tiene la misma cantidad de ambos lados de la pared. Aunque esté en igualdad, las moléculas siguen moviéndose de un lado a otro. Pero no hay cambios netos en las cantidades de cada lado.

NGSS_matched_standards.description: Use a model to illustrate that cellular respiration is a chemical process whereby the bonds of food molecules and oxygen molecules are broken and the bonds in new compounds are formed, resulting in a net transfer of energy.
Refine the design of a chemical system by specifying a change in conditions that would produce increased amounts of products at equilibrium.
Use a model to illustrate the role of cellular division (mitosis) and differentiation in producing and maintaining complex organisms.
Develop and use a model to illustrate the hierarchical organization of interacting systems that provide specific functions within multicellular organisms.
Develop a model to illustrate that the release or absorption of energy from a chemical reaction system depends upon the changes in total bond energy.

english_text: Earthquakes and Society: Movement of the ground during an earthquake seldom directly causes many deaths or injuries. Instead, most injuries result from the collapse of buildings and other structures or from falling objects and flying glass. Other dangers include landslides, fires, explosions caused by broken electric and gas lines, and floodwaters released from collapsing dams. Tsunamis: An earthquake whose epicenter is on the ocean floor may cause a giant ocean wave called a tsunami, which may cause serious destruction if it crashes into land. A tsunami may begin to form when a sudden drop or rise in the ocean floor occurs because of faulting associated with undersea earthquakes. The drop or rise of the ocean floor causes a large mass of sea water to also drop or rise suddenly. This movement sets into motion a series of long, low waves that increase in height as they near the shore. These waves are tsunamis.
subject: Earthquakes
spanish_translation: Los terremotos causan temblores en la tierra. La gente se lesiona porque los edificios se desploman y los objetos caen. Pueden ocurrir deslizamientos, incendios y aguas fuertes. Las grandes olas marinas pueden hacer mucho daño si entran en la tierra. Se forman cuando el fondo marino se mueve de repente. Imaginen que lanzan una piedra al lago y las olas suben alto.

NGSS_matched_standards.description: Develop a model to illustrate how Earth’s internal and surface processes operate at different spatial and temporal scales to form continental and ocean-floor features.
Analyze geoscience data to make the claim that one change to Earth's surface can create feedbacks that cause changes to other Earth systems.
Evaluate evidence of the past and current movements of continental and oceanic crust and the theory of plate tectonics to explain the ages of crustal rocks.
Construct an explanation based on evidence for how the availability of natural resources, occurrence of natural hazards, and changes in climate have influenced human activity.
Plan and conduct an investigation of the properties of water and its effects on Earth materials and surface processes.

english_text: Great Circles: A great circle is often used in navigation, especially by long- distance aircraft. A great circle is any circle that divides the globe into halves, or marks the circumference of the globe. Any circle formed by two meridians of longitude that are directly across the globe from each other is a great circle. The equator is the only line of latitude that is a great circle. Great circles can run in any direction around the globe. Just as a straight line is the shortest distance between two points on a flat surface or plane, the route along a great circle is the shortest distance between two points on a sphere, as shown in Figure 3. As a result, air and sea routes often travel along great circles.
subject: Models of the Earth
spanish_translation: Círculos Grandes: Un círculo grande es como una línea recta que divide la Tierra por la mitad, o que recorre todo su perímetro. Estas líneas se llaman meridianos y están en el cielo, cruzando la Tierra de un lado a otro. El ecuador es una de estas líneas especiales. Los círculos grandes pueden ir en cualquier dirección alrededor del planeta. Aunque una línea recta es la forma más corta de ir de un lugar a otro en una superficie plana, en la Tierra redonda, el camino más corto entre dos puntos es a lo largo de un círculo grande, como se muestra en la Figura 3. Por eso, los aviones y los barcos a menudo siguen estas rutas.

NGSS_matched_standards.description: Use mathematical or computational representations to predict the motion of orbiting objects in the solar system.
Develop a model to illustrate how Earth’s internal and surface processes operate at different spatial and temporal scales to form continental and ocean-floor features.
Develop a quantitative model to describe the cycling of carbon among the hydrosphere, atmosphere, geosphere, and biosphere.
Communicate scientific ideas about the way stars, over their life cycle, produce elements.
