english_text: Contact Metamorphism: When magma comes into contact with existing rock, heat from the magma can change the structure and mineral composition of the surrounding rock by a process called contact metamorphism. contact metamorphism. This process forms the hornfels shown on the previous page. During contact metamorphism only a small area of rock that sur- rounds the hot magma is changed by the magma’s heat. Hot chemical fluids moving through fractures may also cause changes in the surrounding rock during contact metamorphism.
subject: Rocks
spanish_translation: Metamorfismo de contacto: Cuando el magma entra en contacto con una roca existente, el calor del magma puede modificar la estructura y la composición mineral de la roca circundante a través de un proceso llamado metamorfismo de contacto. Este proceso forma los hornfels que se muestran en la página anterior. Durante el metamorfismo de contacto, solo una pequeña área de roca que rodea al magma caliente es transformada por el calor del magma. Los fluidos químicos calientes que se mueven a través de las fracturas también pueden causar cambios en la roca circundante durante el metamorfismo de contacto.

NGSS_matched_standards.description: Analyze geoscience data to make the claim that one change to Earth's surface can create feedbacks that cause changes to other Earth systems.
Evaluate evidence of the past and current movements of continental and oceanic crust and the theory of plate tectonics to explain the ages of crustal rocks.
Develop and use a model of two objects interacting through electric or magnetic fields to illustrate the forces between objects and the changes in energy of the objects due to the interaction.
Apply scientific reasoning and evidence from ancient Earth materials, meteorites, and other planetary surfaces to construct an account of Earth’s formation and early history.
Communicate scientific and technical information about why the molecular-level structure is important in the functioning of designed materials.

english_text: Organic Sedimentary Rock: The second class of sedimentary rock is organic sedimentary organic sedimentary rock. rock. Organic sedimentary rock is rock that forms from the remains of living things. Coal and some limestones are examples of organic sedimentary rocks. Coal forms from plant remains that are buried before they decay and are then compacted into matter that is com- posed mostly of carbon. While chemical limestones precipitate from chemicals dis- solved in water, organic limestones form when marine organisms, such as coral, clams, oysters, and plankton, remove the chemical components of the minerals calcite and aragonite from sea water. These organisms make their shells from these minerals. When they die, their shells eventually become limestone. This process of lime- stone formation is shown in Figure 2. Chalk is one example of limestone made up of the shells of tiny, one-celled marine organ- isms that settle to the ocean floor.
subject: Rocks
spanish_translation: La roca sedimentaria orgánica es como construir una casa con cosas que encontramos en la naturaleza. Se forma cuando las plantas y los animales del mar dejan sus restos y se convierten en piedra. El carbón es como hacer un muro con hojas y ramas presionadas. La piedra caliza es como poner un techo de conchas y huesos. Cuando los animales marinos mueren, sus conchas y huesos se convierten en una roca fuerte, como si estuviéramos construyendo una casa con materiales que encontramos y que, con el tiempo, se convierten en algo sólido y hermoso.

NGSS_matched_standards.description: Develop a quantitative model to describe the cycling of carbon among the hydrosphere, atmosphere, geosphere, and biosphere.
Develop a model to illustrate the role of photosynthesis and cellular respiration in the cycling of carbon among the biosphere, atmosphere, hydrosphere, and geosphere.

english_text: In the previous lesson, we compared cell walls and cell membranes to the roof and walls of a factory. When you think about how cells move materials in and out, it might be more helpful to think of a cell as a nation. The boundaries of a nation are its borders, and nearly every nation tries to regulate and control the goods that move across its borders, like the shipping containers seen here entering and leaving a seaport.
subject: Cell Transport
spanish_translation: En la lección anterior, comparábamos las paredes y membranas celulares con el techo y las paredes de una fábrica. Para entender cómo las células mueven cosas, piénsalo así: una célula es como un país. Los límites de un país son sus fronteras, y la mayoría intenta controlar lo que entra y sale, como los paquetes en un puerto.

english_text: Transmission Electron Microscopes: These microscopes make it possible to explore cell structures and large protein molecules. Beams of electrons can only pass through thin samples, so cells and tissues must be cut into extremely thin slices before they can be examined. This is the reason that such images often appear flat and two dimensional.
subject: Life is Cellular
spanish_translation: Los microscopios electrónicos de transmisión: Estos microscopios nos ayudan a ver las estructuras de las células y las grandes moléculas de proteínas. Los rayos de electrones solo pueden pasar por las muestras finas, así que debemos cortar las células y los tejidos en rebanadas muy delgadas antes de observarlas. Por eso, estas imágenes a menudo se ven planas y sin profundidad.

NGSS_matched_standards.description: Plan and conduct an investigation to gather evidence to compare the structure of substances at the bulk scale to infer the strength of electrical forces between particles.
Communicate scientific and technical information about why the molecular-level structure is important in the functioning of designed materials.

english_text: Identifying Minerals: Earth scientists called mineralogists mineralogists examine, analyze, and classify minerals. To identify minerals, mineralogists study the properties of the minerals. Some properties are simple to study, while special equipment may be needed to study other properties. Physical Properties of Minerals: Each mineral has specific properties that are a result of its chemical composition and crystalline structure. These properties provide useful clues for identifying minerals. Many of these properties can be identified by simply looking at a sample of the mineral. Other properties can be identified through simple tests.
subject: Minerals of Earth's Crust
spanish_translation: Los científicos que estudian los minerales se llaman mineralógos. Para saber qué mineral es, ellos miran las cosas que puedes ver fácilmente. Algunas son sencillas, pero otras necesitan herramientas especiales. Cada mineral tiene características especiales que lo hacen único. Estas características ayudan a identificarlos. Por ejemplo, puedes ver el color y la textura de un mineral con solo mirarlo. También hay pruebas fáciles para descubrir más.

NGSS_matched_standards.description: Plan and conduct an investigation of the properties of water and its effects on Earth materials and surface processes.
Analyze geoscience data to make the claim that one change to Earth's surface can create feedbacks that cause changes to other Earth systems.

english_text: Types of Maps: Earth scientists use a wide variety of maps that show many dis- tinct characteristics of an area. Some of these characteristics include types of rocks, differences in air pressure, and varying depths of groundwater in a region. Scientists also use maps that show locations, elevations, and surface features of Earth.
subject: Models of the Earth
spanish_translation: Tipos de mapas: Los científicos de la Tierra utilizan una amplia variedad de mapas que muestran muchas características distintas de una zona. Algunas de estas características incluyen tipos de rocas, diferencias en la presión del aire y profundidades variables de las aguas subterráneas en una región. Los científicos también usan mapas que indican ubicaciones, elevaciones y características de la superficie de la Tierra.

NGSS_matched_standards.description: Develop a model to illustrate how Earth’s internal and surface processes operate at different spatial and temporal scales to form continental and ocean-floor features.
Analyze geoscience data to make the claim that one change to Earth's surface can create feedbacks that cause changes to other Earth systems.

Plan and conduct an investigation of the properties of water and its effects on Earth materials and surface processes.

english_text: Conic Projections: A projection made by placing a paper cone over a lighted globe so that the axis of the cone aligns with the axis of the globe is known as a conic projection. The cone touches the globe along one parallel of latitude. As shown in Figure 4, areas near the parallel where the cone and globe are in contact are distorted the least.
subject: Models of the Earth
spanish_translation: Proyecciones cónicas: Es una proyección que se realiza colocando un cono de papel sobre un globo iluminado, de modo que el eje del cono se alinea con el eje del globo. El cono toca el globo a lo largo de un paralelo de latitud. Como se muestra en la Figura 4, las áreas cerca del paralelo donde el cono y el globo están en contacto se distorsionan menos.

NGSS_matched_standards.description: Analyze geoscience data to make the claim that one change to Earth's surface can create feedbacks that cause changes to other Earth systems.

english_text: Heterogeneous Mixtures: Mixtures in which two or more substances are not uniformly distributed are called heterogeneous mixtures. For example, the igneous rock granite is a heterogeneous mixture of crystals of the minerals quartz, feldspar, hornblende, and biotite. Homogeneous Mixtures: In chemistry, the word homogeneous means “having the same composition and properties throughout.” A homogeneous mixture of two or more substances that are uniformly dispersed through- out the mixture is a solution. solution. Any part of a given sample of the solution known as sea water, for example, will have the same composition. Sodium chloride, NaCl, (along with many other ionic compounds) is dissolved in sea water. The positive ends of water molecules attract negative chloride ions. And the negative ends of water molecules attract positive sodium ions. Eventually, all of the sodium and chloride ions become uniformly distributed among the water molecules. Gases and solids can also be solutions. An alloy is a solution composed of two or more metals. The steel shown in Figure 6 is an example of such a solution, both in liquid and solid states.
subject: Earth Chemistry
spanish_translation: Una mezcla heterogénea es como un grupo donde algunas personas están juntas y otras están separadas. Por ejemplo, el granito es una roca con diferentes tipos de cristales.

Los límites de un país son sus fronteras, y los países tratan de controlar lo que entra y sale, como los camiones que llevan cosas al puerto.

english_text: Great Circles: A great circle is often used in navigation, especially by long- distance aircraft. A great circle is any circle that divides the globe into halves, or marks the circumference of the globe. Any circle formed by two meridians of longitude that are directly across the globe from each other is a great circle. The equator is the only line of latitude that is a great circle. Great circles can run in any direction around the globe. Just as a straight line is the shortest distance between two points on a flat surface or plane, the route along a great circle is the shortest distance between two points on a sphere, as shown in Figure 3. As a result, air and sea routes often travel along great circles.
subject: Models of the Earth
spanish_translation: Los círculos grandes son líneas especiales que ayudan a los aviones a volar más rápido. Dividen la Tierra en dos partes iguales. Piensa en una línea recta que recorre el centro de la Tierra; ¡eso es un círculo grande! El ecuador es una línea que rodea la Tierra. Estos círculos pueden ir en todas las direcciones. Al igual que un camino directo es el más corto, un círculo grande es la forma más rápida de viajar alrededor del mundo, como se muestra en la Figura 3. Por eso, los aviones y barcos a menudo siguen estos caminos.

english_text: Earthquakes and Society: Movement of the ground during an earthquake seldom directly causes many deaths or injuries. Other dangers include landslides, fires, explosions caused by broken electric and gas lines, and floodwaters released from collapsing dams. A tsunami may begin to form when a sudden drop or rise in the ocean floor occurs because of faulting associated with undersea earthquakes. The drop or rise of the ocean floor causes a large mass of sea water to also drop or rise suddenly. This movement sets into motion a series of long, low waves that increase in height as they near the shore. These waves are tsunamis.
subject: Earthquakes
spanish_translation: Los terremotos y sus consecuencias: Cuando la tierra tiembla, el suelo puede moverse, pero no siempre nos hace daño directamente. Lo que puede lastimarnos son los edificios que se caen o los objetos que caen y rompen cosas. También hay otros peligros como las rocas que se desprenden, los incendios y el agua que sube de las presas rotas.

NGSS_matched_standards.description: Develop a model to illustrate how Earth’s internal and surface processes operate at different spatial and temporal scales to form continental and ocean-floor features.

english_text: Earthquakes Away from Plate Boundaries: Not all earthquakes result from movement along plate boundaries. A widely felt series of earthquakes occurred in the United States far from any active plate boundary. Instead, these earth- quakes occurred in the middle of the continent, near New Madrid, Missouri, in 1811 and 1812. The vibrations from the earthquakes that rocked New Madrid were so strong that they caused damage as far away as South Carolina. It was not until the late 1970s that studies of the Mississippi River region revealed an ancient fault zone deep within Earth’s crust. This zone is thought to be part of a major fault zone in the North American plate. Scientists have determined that the fault formed at least 600 million years ago and that it was later buried under many layers of sediment and rock.
subject: Earthquakes
spanish_translation: Terremotos lejos de las fronteras de placas: No todos los terremotos son causados por el movimiento a lo largo de las fronteras de placas. Ocurrió una serie de terremotos sentidos en gran parte de los Estados Unidos lejos de cualquier frontera de placa activa. En lugar de eso, estos terremotos ocurrieron en el centro del continente, cerca de New Madrid, Misuri, en 1811 y 1812. Las vibraciones de los terremotos que sacudieron New Madrid fueron tan fuertes que causaron daños tan lejos como Carolina del Sur. No fue hasta finales de los años 70 que los estudios de la región del río Mississippi revelaron una antigua zona de falla profunda en la corteza terrestre. Se cree que esta zona es parte de una importante zona de falla en la placa norteamericana. Los científicos han determinado que la falla se formó hace al menos 600 millones de años y que más tarde fue enterrada bajo muchos capas de sedimentos y rocas.

Some of these characteristics include types of rocks, differences in air pressure, and varying depths of groundwater in a region. Scientists also use maps that show locations, elevations, and surface features of Earth.
subject: Models of the Earth
spanish_translation: Tipos de mapas: Los científicos de la Tierra usan muchos mapas que muestran cosas diferentes de un lugar. Estos mapas hablan de tipos de piedras, cómo cambia el aire y cuán profundo es el agua bajo tierra. También usan mapas que muestran dónde están las cosas, cuán alto o bajo es el terreno y cómo es la superficie.

NGSS_matched_standards.description: Develop a model to illustrate how Earth’s internal and surface processes operate at different spatial and temporal scales to form continental and ocean-floor features.
Analyze geoscience data to make the claim that one change to Earth's surface can create feedbacks that cause changes to other Earth systems.
Use a computational representation to illustrate the relationships among Earth systems and how those relationships are being modified due to human activity.

Analyze geoscience data and the results from global climate models to make an evidence-based forecast of the current rate of global or regional climate change and associated future impacts to Earth's systems.
Plan and conduct an investigation of the properties of water and its effects on Earth materials and surface processes.

english_text: The Rock Cycle: Any of the three major types of rock can be changed into another of the three types. Geologic forces and processes cause rock to change from one type to another. This series of changes is called the rock cycle,  which is shown in Figure 2. One starting point for examining the steps of the rock cycle is igneous rock. When a body of igneous rock is exposed at Earth’s surface, a number of processes break down the igneous rock into sediment. When sediment from igneous rocks is compacted and cemented, the sediment becomes sedimentary rock. Then, if sedimentary rocks are subjected to changes in temperature and pressure, the rocks may become metamorphic rocks. Under certain temperature and pressure conditions, the metamorphic rock will melt and form magma. Then, if the magma cools, new igneous rock will form. Much of the rock in Earth’s continental crust has probably passed through the rock cycle many times during Earth’s history. However, as Figure 2 shows, a particular body of rock does not always pass through each stage of the rock cycle.
subject: Rocks
spanish_translation: El Ciclo de las Rocas: Las tres clases de rocas pueden cambiarse entre sí. La tierra y los procesos naturales hacen que las rocas cambien de tipo. Esta serie de cambios se llama ciclo de las rocas, como se muestra en la Figura 2. Una buena forma de ver los pasos del ciclo es empezar con la roca ígnea. Cuando un pedazo de roca ígnea sale a la superficie de la Tierra, el agua y el viento la descomponen en pequeños pedazos. Estos pedazos, cuando se apretan y se unen, se convierten en roca sedimentaria. Si la roca sedimentaria se calienta mucho o se presiona fuerte, puede transformarse en roca metamórfica. Luego, bajo ciertas condiciones, esta roca se derrite y forma magma. Cuando el magma se enfría, se crea nueva roca ígnea. Muchas rocas en la parte dura de la Tierra han pasado por este ciclo muchas veces a lo largo de su historia. Pero, como ves en la Figura 2, cada roca no siempre pasa por todos los pasos del ciclo.

english_text: In the past decade, new microscopes have been developed that use precise, computer controlled laser beams to scan across samples and gather very high resolution information. These instruments and techniques are making it possible to study living cells at a level of detail never possible before, opening up even more opportunities for research.
subject: Life is Cellular
spanish_translation: En los últimos años, se han creado microscopios nuevos que usan rayos láser muy precisos y controlados por ordenadores para ver dentro de las muestras. Esto nos permite estudiar las células vivas con un detalle increíble, como si pudiéramos ver un mundo diminuto. ¡Esto ayuda a los científicos a descubrir muchas cosas nuevas!

NGSS_matched_standards.description: Use a model to illustrate the role of cellular division (mitosis) and differentiation in producing and maintaining complex organisms.
Construct an explanation based on evidence for how the structure of DNA determines the structure of proteins, which carry out the essential functions of life through systems of specialized cells.

Communicate technical information about how some technological devices use the principles of wave behavior and wave interactions with matter to transmit and capture information and energy.
Develop and use a model to illustrate the hierarchical organization of interacting systems that provide specific functions within multicellular organisms.

english_text: A series of conic projections may be used to increase accuracy by mapping a number of neighboring areas. Each cone touches the globe at a slightly different latitude. Fitting the adjoining areas together then produces a continuous map. Maps made in this way are called polyconic projections. The relative size and shape of small areas on the map are nearly the same as those on the globe.
subject: Models of the Earth
spanish_translation: Para aumentar la precisión al cartografiar áreas vecinas, se utiliza una serie de proyecciones cónicas, donde cada cono hace contacto con el globo terráqueo en una latitud ligeramente distinta. La combinación de estas áreas contiguas genera un mapa continuo. Los mapas creados mediante este método se denominan proyecciones policónicas. Este tipo de proyección logra que el tamaño y la forma relativos de las áreas pequeñas en el mapa sean casi idénticos a los del globo, minimizando así la distorsión.

NGSS_matched_standards.description: Develop a model to illustrate how Earth’s internal and surface processes operate at different spatial and temporal scales to form continental and ocean-floor features.

english_text: In the previous lesson, we compared cell walls and cell membranes to the roof and walls of a factory. When you think about how cells move materials in and out, it might be more helpful to think of a cell as a nation. The boundaries of a nation are its borders, and nearly every nation tries to regulate and control the goods that move across its borders, like the shipping containers seen here entering and leaving a seaport.
subject: Cell Transport
spanish_translation: En la lección anterior, comparamos la pared celular y la membrana celular con el techo y las paredes de una fábrica. Para entender cómo las células mueven materiales hacia adentro y hacia afuera, puede ser más útil pensar en una célula como si fuera un país. Los límites de un país son sus fronteras, y casi todos los países intentan regular y controlar los productos que cruzan sus fronteras, como los contenedores de carga que se ven aquí entrando y saliendo de un puerto.

english_text: Soil Surveys: A soil survey consists of three main parts: text, maps, and tables. The text of soil surveys includes general information about the geology, topography, and climate of the area being mapped. The tables describe the types and volumes of soils in the area. Soil surveys generally include two types of soil maps. The first type is a very general map that shows the approximate location of different types of soil within the area, such as the one shown in Figure 5. The second type shows detailed information about soils in the area. Uses of Soil Maps: Soil maps are valuable tools for agriculture and land management. Knowing the properties of the soil in an area helps farmers, agricultural engineers, and government agencies identify ways to conserve and use soil and to plan sites for future development.
subject: Models of the Earth
spanish_translation: Estudios Edafológicos: Un estudio edafológico, o levantamiento de suelos, se compone de tres elementos principales: una memoria descriptiva (texto), cartografía (mapas) y tablas de datos. La memoria descriptiva proporciona un panorama general de las características geológicas, topográficas y climáticas de la zona cartografiada. Las tablas detallan la clasificación taxonómica y los volúmenes de las distintas unidades de suelo presentes en el área. Generalmente, los estudios edafológicos incluyen dos tipos de cartografía. La primera es un mapa a escala general que ilustra la distribución aproximada de las principales asociaciones de suelos en la región, como el mostrado en la Figura 5. La segunda consiste en una cartografía de detalle que ofrece información exhaustiva sobre las propiedades fisicoquímicas y el perfil de los suelos. Aplicaciones de la Cartografía Edafológica: Los mapas de suelos constituyen herramientas de gran valor para la agronomía y el ordenamiento territorial. El conocimiento de las propiedades edáficas de una zona permite a agricultores, ingenieros agrónomos y entidades gubernamentales optimizar las estrategias de conservación y manejo del recurso suelo, así como planificar el desarrollo de infraestructuras y futuros emplazamientos.

NGSS_matched_standards.description: Analyze geoscience data to make the claim that one change to Earth's surface can create feedbacks that cause changes to other Earth systems.

english_text: Organic Sedimentary Rock: The second class of sedimentary rock is organic sedimentary organic sedimentary rock. rock. Organic sedimentary rock is rock that forms from the remains of living things. Coal and some limestones are examples of organic sedimentary rocks. Coal forms from plant remains that are buried before they decay and are then compacted into matter that is com- posed mostly of carbon. While chemical limestones precipitate from chemicals dis- solved in water, organic limestones form when marine organisms, such as coral, clams, oysters, and plankton, remove the chemical components of the minerals calcite and aragonite from sea water. These organisms make their shells from these minerals. When they die, their shells eventually become limestone. This process of lime- stone formation is shown in Figure 2. Chalk is one example of limestone made up of the shells of tiny, one-celled marine organ- isms that settle to the ocean floor.
subject: Rocks
spanish_translation: Roca Sedimentaria Orgánica: La segunda clase de roca sedimentaria es la roca sedimentaria orgánica. La roca sedimentaria orgánica es la que se forma a partir de los restos de seres vivos. El carbón y algunas rocas calizas son ejemplos de rocas sedimentarias orgánicas. El carbón se forma a partir de restos vegetales que son enterrados antes de que se descompongan y luego son compactados hasta formar una materia compuesta principalmente de carbono. Mientras que las rocas calizas químicas se precipitan a partir de sustancias disueltas en el agua, las calizas orgánicas se forman cuando organismos marinos, como el coral, las almejas, las ostras y el plancton, extraen del agua de mar los componentes químicos de los minerales calcita y aragonita. Estos organismos usan estos minerales para fabricar sus conchas. Cuando mueren, sus conchas con el tiempo se convierten en roca caliza. Este proceso de formación de la roca caliza se muestra en la Figura 2. La tiza es un ejemplo de roca caliza formada por las conchas de diminutos organismos marinos unicelulares que se asientan en el fondo del océano.

NGSS_matched_standards.description: Develop a quantitative model to describe the cycling of carbon among the hydrosphere, atmosphere, geosphere, and biosphere.
Develop a model to illustrate the role of photosynthesis and cellular respiration in the cycling of carbon among the biosphere, atmosphere, hydrosphere, and geosphere.

Construct and revise an explanation based on evidence for how carbon, hydrogen, and oxygen from sugar molecules may combine with other elements to form amino acids and/or other large carbon-based molecules.

Use a model to illustrate that cellular respiration is a chemical process whereby the bonds of food molecules and oxygen molecules are broken and the bonds in new compounds are formed, resulting in a net transfer of energy.

english_text: Contact Metamorphism: When magma comes into contact with existing rock, heat from the magma can change the structure and mineral composition of the surrounding rock by a process called contact metamorphism. contact metamorphism. This process forms the hornfels shown on the previous page. During contact metamorphism only a small area of rock that sur- rounds the hot magma is changed by the magma’s heat. Hot chemical fluids moving through fractures may also cause changes in the surrounding rock during contact metamorphism.
subject: Rocks
spanish_translation: El magma es roca derretida y muy caliente. Cuando toca otras rocas, el calor las cambia. A este cambio se le llama cambio por contacto. Solo cambian las rocas que están muy cerca del magma. A veces, líquidos calientes con químicos entran en las grietas. Estos líquidos también ayudan a que las rocas cambien.

NGSS_matched_standards.description: Analyze geoscience data to make the claim that one change to Earth's surface can create feedbacks that cause changes to other Earth systems.

Develop and use a model of two objects interacting through electric or magnetic fields to illustrate the forces between objects and the changes in energy of the objects due to the interaction.

Communicate scientific and technical information about why the molecular-level structure is important in the functioning of designed materials.

english_text: Organic Sedimentary Rock: The second class of sedimentary rock is organic sedimentary organic sedimentary rock. rock. Organic sedimentary rock is rock that forms from the remains of living things. Coal and some limestones are examples of organic sedimentary rocks. Coal forms from plant remains that are buried before they decay and are then compacted into matter that is com- posed mostly of carbon. While chemical limestones precipitate from chemicals dis- solved in water, organic limestones form when marine organisms, such as coral, clams, oysters, and plankton, remove the chemical components of the minerals calcite and aragonite from sea water. These organisms make their shells from these minerals. When they die, their shells eventually become limestone. This process of lime- stone formation is shown in Figure 2. Chalk is one example of limestone made up of the shells of tiny, one-celled marine organ- isms that settle to the ocean floor.
subject: Rocks
spanish_translation: Algunas rocas son especiales. Se hacen con plantas y animales muy viejos. El carbón es una de estas rocas. Se forma con plantas. Las plantas quedan debajo de la tierra. Se aprietan muy fuerte. Con el tiempo se hacen carbón. Otro tipo de roca se hace en el mar. Los animalitos del mar usan el agua. Con ella hacen sus conchas duras. Cuando mueren, sus conchas caen al fondo del mar. Pasa mucho, mucho tiempo. Las conchas se juntan. Así se convierten en una roca. La tiza es un tipo de esta roca. Se hace con las conchas de muchos animalitos del mar.

NGSS_matched_standards.description: Develop a quantitative model to describe the cycling of carbon among the hydrosphere, atmosphere, geosphere, and biosphere.
Develop a model to illustrate the role of photosynthesis and cellular respiration in the cycling of carbon among the biosphere, atmosphere, hydrosphere, and geosphere.

Construct and revise an explanation based on evidence for how carbon, hydrogen, and oxygen from sugar molecules may combine with other elements to form amino acids and/or other large carbon-based molecules.
Evaluate evidence of the past and current movements of continental and oceanic crust and the theory of plate tectonics to explain the ages of crustal rocks.

Use a model to illustrate that cellular respiration is a chemical process whereby the bonds of food molecules and oxygen molecules are broken and the bonds in new compounds are formed, resulting in a net transfer of energy.

english_text: Polar Covalent Bonds: In many cases, atoms that are covalently bonded do not equally share electrons. The reason for this is that the ability of atoms of some elements to attract electrons from atoms of other elements differs. A covalent bond in which the bonded atoms have an unequal attraction for the shared electrons is called a polar covalent bond. Water is an example of a molecule that forms as a result of polar covalent bonds. Two hydrogen atoms bond covalently with an oxygen atom and form a water molecule. Because the oxygen atom has more ability to attract electrons than the hydrogen atoms do, the electrons are not shared equally between the oxygen and hydrogen atoms. Instead, the electrons remain closer to the oxygen nucleus, which has the greater pull. As a result, the water molecule as a whole has a slightly negative charge at its oxygen end and slightly positive charges at its hydrogen ends. The slightly positive ends of a water molecule attract the slightly negative ends of other water molecules.
subject: Earth Chemistry
spanish_translation: Enlaces Covalentes Polares: En los enlaces covalentes, la compartición de electrones no es siempre equitativa, fenómeno que se origina por las diferencias en la electronegatividad de los átomos involucrados. Un enlace en el que existe una atracción desigual por los electrones compartidos se clasifica como enlace covalente polar. La molécula de agua es un caso ilustrativo; la elevada electronegatividad del oxígeno, en comparación con la del hidrógeno, provoca un desplazamiento de la densidad electrónica hacia el átomo de oxígeno. Esto genera una distribución asimétrica de la carga, resultando en una carga parcial negativa (δ⁻) sobre el oxígeno y cargas parciales positivas (δ⁺) sobre los hidrógenos. La geometría molecular angular del agua, combinada con la polaridad de sus enlaces, origina un momento dipolar neto diferente de cero, lo que la define como una molécula polar. Esta polaridad intrínseca es la que permite que el extremo con carga parcial positiva de una molécula de agua experimente una atracción electrostática hacia el extremo con carga parcial negativa de moléculas adyacentes.

NGSS_matched_standards.description: Plan and conduct an investigation of the properties of water and its effects on Earth materials and surface processes.

Construct and revise an explanation based on evidence for how carbon, hydrogen, and oxygen from sugar molecules may combine with other elements to form amino acids and/or other large carbon-based molecules.
Communicate scientific and technical information about why the molecular-level structure is important in the functioning of designed materials.
Plan and conduct an investigation to gather evidence to compare the structure of substances at the bulk scale to infer the strength of electrical forces between particles.

Construct and revise an explanation for the outcome of a simple chemical reaction based on the outermost electron states of atoms, trends in the periodic table, and knowledge of the patterns of chemical properties.

english_text: Landforms on Topographic Maps: As shown in Figure 3, the spacing and the direction of contour lines indicate the shapes of the landforms represented on a topo- graphic map. Contour lines spaced widely apart indicate that the change in elevation is gradual and that the land is relatively level. Closely spaced contour lines indicate that the change in elevation is rapid and that the slope is steep. A contour line that bends to form a V shape indicates a valley. The bend in the V points toward the higher end of the valley. If a stream or river flows through the valley, the V in the contour line will point upstream, the direction from which the water flows. A river always flows from higher to lower elevation. The width of the V formed by the contour line shows the width of the valley. Contour lines that form closed loops indicate a hilltop or a depression. Generally, a depression is indicated by depression contours, which are closed-loop contour lines that have short, straight lines perpendicular to the inside of the loop. These short lines point toward the center of the depression.
subject: Models of the Earth
spanish_translation: Morfología del terreno en mapas topográficos: Tal como se ilustra en la Figura 3, el espaciado y la orientación de las curvas de nivel determinan las formas del relieve representadas en un mapa topográfico. Mientras que las curvas de nivel con un espaciado amplio indican un cambio de elevación gradual y un terreno relativamente llano, aquellas con un espaciado reducido revelan una pendiente pronunciada y un cambio rápido de elevación, lo que se conoce como un gradiente topográfico elevado. Una curva de nivel que se inflexiona en forma de V representa un valle. El vértice de esta V apunta hacia la zona de mayor elevación del valle. Si un curso de agua, como un río, discurre por el valle, la V apuntará aguas arriba, en la dirección de la que proviene el agua, puesto que un río siempre fluye desde una cota superior a una inferior. La amplitud de la V que forma la curva de nivel es indicativa de la anchura del valle. Las curvas de nivel que forman bucles cerrados señalan la presencia de una cima o una depresión. Generalmente, una depresión se representa mediante curvas de depresión, que son curvas de nivel cerradas con pequeñas líneas perpendiculares en su cara interior, denominadas hachuras. Estas hachuras apuntan hacia el centro de la depresión.

NGSS_matched_standards.description: Develop a model to illustrate how Earth’s internal and surface processes operate at different spatial and temporal scales to form continental and ocean-floor features.
Use a model to describe how variations in the flow of energy into and out of Earth’s systems result in changes in climate.
Use a computational representation to illustrate the relationships among Earth systems and how those relationships are being modified due to human activity.
Use mathematical representations to support and revise explanations based on evidence about factors affecting biodiversity and populations in ecosystems of different scales.
Use mathematical and/or computational representations to support explanations of factors that affect carrying capacity of ecosystems at different scales.

english_text: Heterogeneous Mixtures: Mixtures in which two or more substances are not uniformly distributed are called heterogeneous mixtures. For example, the igneous rock granite is a heterogeneous mixture of crystals of the minerals quartz, feldspar, hornblende, and biotite. Homogeneous Mixtures: In chemistry, the word homogeneous means “having the same composition and properties throughout.” A homogeneous mixture of two or more substances that are uniformly dispersed through- out the mixture is a solution. solution. Any part of a given sample of the solution known as sea water, for example, will have the same composition. Sodium chloride, NaCl, (along with many other ionic compounds) is dissolved in sea water. The positive ends of water molecules attract negative chloride ions. And the negative ends of water molecules attract positive sodium ions. Eventually, all of the sodium and chloride ions become uniformly distributed among the water molecules. Gases and solids can also be solutions. An alloy is a solution composed of two or more metals. The steel shown in Figure 6 is an example of such a solution, both in liquid and solid states.
subject: Earth Chemistry
spanish_translation: Mezclas heterogéneas: Se caracterizan por una distribución no uniforme de sus componentes, lo que resulta en la presencia de fases física y químicamente distintas. Un ejemplo geológico es el granito, una roca ígnea que exhibe una mezcla macroscópica de cristales de minerales como cuarzo, feldespato, hornblenda y biotita, cada uno conservando sus propiedades individuales. Mezclas homogéneas (Soluciones): En contraste, las mezclas homogéneas o soluciones presentan una única fase con composición y propiedades uniformes en toda su extensión, independientemente de la concentración molar de sus componentes. El agua de mar es un ejemplo canónico de una solución acuosa. En ella, la disolución de compuestos iónicos como el cloruro de sodio (NaCl) se rige por el principio de solvatación. Las fuerzas intermoleculares, específicamente las interacciones ión-dipolo, son responsables de este fenómeno: la polaridad de la molécula de agua permite que sus extremos positivos rodeen y estabilicen a los aniones (Cl⁻), mientras que sus extremos negativos lo hacen con los cationes (Na⁺). Este proceso asegura una dispersión iónica homogénea en el disolvente. La formación de soluciones no se limita al estado líquido; también existen soluciones gaseosas y sólidas. Las aleaciones metálicas, como el acero (Figura 6), son un ejemplo primordial de soluciones en estado sólido, cuya estructura y propiedades pueden ser analizadas mediante diagramas de fase que describen su comportamiento tanto en estado líquido como sólido.

NGSS_matched_standards.description: Plan and conduct an investigation of the properties of water and its effects on Earth materials and surface processes.
Develop a model to illustrate how Earth’s internal and surface processes operate at different spatial and temporal scales to form continental and ocean-floor features.

Construct and revise an explanation based on evidence for how carbon, hydrogen, and oxygen from sugar molecules may combine with other elements to form amino acids and/or other large carbon-based molecules.

Refine the design of a chemical system by specifying a change in conditions that would produce increased amounts of products at equilibrium.

english_text: Sorting: The tendency for currents of air or water to separate sediments according to size is called sorting. Sediments can be very well sorted, very poorly sorted, or somewhere in between, as shown in Figure 4. In well-sorted sediments, all of the grains are roughly the same size and shape. Poorly sorted sediment consists of grains that are many different sizes. The sorting of a sediment is the result of changes in the speed of the agent that is moving the sediment. For example, when a fast-moving stream enters a lake, the speed of the water decreases sharply. Because large grains are too heavy for the current to carry, these grains are deposited first. Fine grains can stay suspended in the water for much longer than large grains can. So, fine particles are commonly deposited farther from shore or on top of coarser sediments.
subject: Rocks
spanish_translation: El viento y el agua mueven las rocas chiquitas. A veces las ordenan por su tamaño. Cuando todas son iguales, están bien ordenadas. Cuando hay grandes y chicas mezcladas, están mal ordenadas. A veces el agua va muy rápido. Otras veces va lento. Imagina un río que va rápido. Llega a un lago y va más despacio. El agua ya no empuja tan fuerte. Las piedras grandes se caen primero. Se van al fondo. Los pedacitos chicos flotan más. Por eso, caen más lejos. También caen encima de las piedras grandes.

NGSS_matched_standards.description: Develop a model to illustrate how Earth’s internal and surface processes operate at different spatial and temporal scales to form continental and ocean-floor features.
Develop a quantitative model to describe the cycling of carbon among the hydrosphere, atmosphere, geosphere, and biosphere.

Evaluate claims, evidence, and reasoning that the complex interactions in ecosystems maintain relatively consistent numbers and types of organisms in stable conditions, but changing conditions may result in a new ecosystem.

english_text: Passive Transport Every living cell exists in a liquid environment. One of the most important processes carried out by the cell membrane is to keep a cell in homeostasis. Homeostasis is a state of relatively constant internal physical and chemical conditions. It does this by regulating the movement of molecules and other substances from one side of the membrane to the other side.
subject: Cell Transport
spanish_translation: Transporte Pasivo. Toda célula viva está rodeada de líquido. La célula tiene una capa que la protege, como si fuera su piel. Esta capa se llama membrana y es como un portero. Su trabajo es mantener el equilibrio dentro de la célula. Así, la célula se mantiene sana. La membrana decide qué cosas pequeñas pueden entrar y qué cosas pueden salir.

NGSS_matched_standards.description: Use a model to illustrate that cellular respiration is a chemical process whereby the bonds of food molecules and oxygen molecules are broken and the bonds in new compounds are formed, resulting in a net transfer of energy.
Develop and use a model to illustrate the hierarchical organization of interacting systems that provide specific functions within multicellular organisms.
Use a model to illustrate the role of cellular division (mitosis) and differentiation in producing and maintaining complex organisms.
Construct and revise an explanation based on evidence for the cycling of matter and flow of energy in aerobic and anaerobic conditions.
Use mathematical representations to support claims for the cycling of matter and flow of energy among organisms in an ecosystem.

english_text: How Osmosis Works Look at the experimental setup in Figure 8-19A. The barrier is permeable to water but not to sugar. This means that water can cross the barrier in both directions, but sugar cannot. To start, there are more sugar molecules on the right side of the barrier than on the left side. Therefore, the concentration of water is lower on the right, where more of the solution is made of sugar. Although water molecules move in both directions across the membrane, there is a net transport of water toward the concentrated sugar solution. Water will tend to move across the membrane until equilibrium is reached.
subject: Cell Transport
spanish_translation: Cómo funciona la ósmosis. Observa el experimento en la Figura 8-19A. La barrera deja pasar el agua, pero no el azúcar. Esto quiere decir que el agua puede cruzar la barrera en ambas direcciones, pero el azúcar no. Al inicio, hay más moléculas de azúcar del lado derecho de la barrera que del izquierdo. Por esta razón, la concentración de agua es más baja en el lado derecho, donde la solución tiene más azúcar. Aunque las moléculas de agua se mueven en ambas direcciones, en total, más agua se mueve hacia la solución de azúcar más concentrada. El agua tenderá a moverse a través de la barrera hasta que se alcance un equilibrio.

NGSS_matched_standards.description: Use a model to illustrate that cellular respiration is a chemical process whereby the bonds of food molecules and oxygen molecules are broken and the bonds in new compounds are formed, resulting in a net transfer of energy.
Use mathematical representations to support claims for the cycling of matter and flow of energy among organisms in an ecosystem.
Plan and conduct an investigation of the properties of water and its effects on Earth materials and surface processes.
Use a model to illustrate how photosynthesis transforms light energy into stored chemical energy.
Develop a model to illustrate the role of photosynthesis and cellular respiration in the cycling of carbon among the biosphere, atmosphere, hydrosphere, and geosphere.

english_text: The Nucleus: In the same way that the main office controls a large factory, the nucleus is the control center of the cell. The nucleus contains nearly all the cell’s DNA and, with it, the coded instructions for making proteins and other important molecules. Only eukaryotic cells have a nucleus. In prokaryotic cells, DNA is found in the cytoplasm.
subject: Cell Structure
spanish_translation: El Núcleo: El núcleo es como el cerebro de la célula. Es el jefe. Da todas las órdenes. Controla todo lo que pasa adentro. Dentro del núcleo está el ADN. El ADN es como un libro de instrucciones. Le dice a la célula cómo crecer. También le dice qué trabajo hacer.

NGSS_matched_standards.description: Construct an explanation based on evidence for how the structure of DNA determines the structure of proteins, which carry out the essential functions of life through systems of specialized cells.
Use a model to illustrate the role of cellular division (mitosis) and differentiation in producing and maintaining complex organisms.
Develop and use a model to illustrate the hierarchical organization of interacting systems that provide specific functions within multicellular organisms.
Develop models to illustrate the changes in the composition of the nucleus of the atom and the energy released during the processes of fission, fusion, and radioactive decay.
Ask questions to clarify relationships about the role of DNA and chromosomes in coding the instructions for characteristic traits passed from parents to offspring.

english_text: How Scientists Make Maps: The science of making maps, called cartography, is a subfield of Earth science and geography. Scientists who make maps are called cartographers. Cartographers use data from a variety of sources to create maps. They may collect data by conducting a field survey, shown in Figure 1. During a field survey, cartographers walk or drive through an area to be mapped and make measurements of that area. The information they collect is then plotted on a map. Because surveyors cannot take measurements at every site in an area, they often use their measurements to make estimated measurements for sites between surveyed points. By using remote sensing, cartographers can collect information about a site without being at that site. In remote sensing, remote sensing, equipment on satellites or airplanes obtains images of Earth’s surface. Maps are often made by combining information from images gathered remotely with information from field surveys.
subject: Models of the Earth
spanish_translation: Las personas que dibujan mapas necesitan saber muchas cosas. Una forma es ir al lugar. Ellos caminan por el sitio. Miden qué tan lejos están las cosas. Luego, lo dibujan en un mapa. Otra forma es tomar fotos desde el cielo. Usan cámaras en los aviones. También usan naves que dan vueltas a la Tierra. Esas naves toman fotos de nuestro planeta. Para hacer un mapa muy bueno, usan todo lo que saben. Usan las medidas del suelo. También usan las fotos del cielo.

NGSS_matched_standards.description: Analyze geoscience data to make the claim that one change to Earth's surface can create feedbacks that cause changes to other Earth systems.
Use a computational representation to illustrate the relationships among Earth systems and how those relationships are being modified due to human activity.
Apply scientific reasoning and evidence from ancient Earth materials, meteorites, and other planetary surfaces to construct an account of Earth’s formation and early history.
Develop a model to illustrate how Earth’s internal and surface processes operate at different spatial and temporal scales to form continental and ocean-floor features.

Analyze geoscience data and the results from global climate models to make an evidence-based forecast of the current rate of global or regional climate change and associated future impacts to Earth's systems.

english_text: Atomic Structure: Even though atoms are very tiny, they are made up of even smaller parts called subatomic particles. The three major kinds of subatomic particles are protons, electrons, and neutrons. Protons are  subatomic particles that have a positive charge. Electrons are subatomic particles that have a negative charge. Neutrons are sub- atomic particles that are neutral, which means that they have no charge.
subject: Earth Chemistry
spanish_translation: Estructura Atómica: Aunque los átomos son muy pequeños, están compuestos por partes aún más pequeñas llamadas partículas subatómicas. Los tres tipos principales de partículas subatómicas son los protones, los electrones y los neutrones. Los protones son partículas subatómicas que tienen una carga positiva. Los electrones son partículas subatómicas que tienen una carga negativa. Los neutrones son partículas subatómicas que son neutras, lo que significa que no tienen carga.

NGSS_matched_standards.description: Plan and conduct an investigation to gather evidence to compare the structure of substances at the bulk scale to infer the strength of electrical forces between particles.
Develop models to illustrate the changes in the composition of the nucleus of the atom and the energy released during the processes of fission, fusion, and radioactive decay.
Use the periodic table as a model to predict the relative properties of elements based on the patterns of electrons in the outermost energy level of atoms.

Construct and revise an explanation for the outcome of a simple chemical reaction based on the outermost electron states of atoms, trends in the periodic table, and knowledge of the patterns of chemical properties.

Construct and revise an explanation based on evidence for how carbon, hydrogen, and oxygen from sugar molecules may combine with other elements to form amino acids and/or other large carbon-based molecules.

english_text: Conic Projections: A projection made by placing a paper cone over a lighted globe so that the axis of the cone aligns with the axis of the globe is known as a conic projection. The cone touches the globe along one parallel of latitude. As shown in Figure 4, areas near the parallel where the cone and globe are in contact are distorted the least.
subject: Models of the Earth
spanish_translation: Mapas con forma de cono: Imagina un cono de papel. Es como un sombrero de fiesta. Pones el cono sobre un globo. El papel toca el globo en un círculo. Los lugares cerca de ese círculo se ven bien. Su forma es casi la real. Los lugares más lejanos se ven estirados.

NGSS_matched_standards.description: Analyze geoscience data to make the claim that one change to Earth's surface can create feedbacks that cause changes to other Earth systems.
Design, build, and refine a device that works within given constraints to convert one form of energy into another form of energy.
Develop a model to illustrate how Earth’s internal and surface processes operate at different spatial and temporal scales to form continental and ocean-floor features.

english_text: For example, igneous rock may never be exposed at Earth’s surface where the rock could change into sediment. Instead, the igneous rock may change directly into metamorphic rock while still beneath Earth’s surface. Sedimentary rock may be broken down at Earth’s surface, and the sediment may become another sedimentary rock. Metamorphic rock can be altered by heat and pressure to form a different type of metamorphic rock.
subject: Rocks
spanish_translation: A veces, una roca ígnea se queda muy adentro de la Tierra y no sale a la superficie. Allí abajo hace mucho calor. Además, todo el peso de la tierra la aprieta muy fuerte. El calor y toda esa fuerza que la aprieta cambian la roca. Así se transforma en una roca metamórfica.

NGSS_matched_standards.description: Analyze geoscience data to make the claim that one change to Earth's surface can create feedbacks that cause changes to other Earth systems.
Develop a model to illustrate how Earth’s internal and surface processes operate at different spatial and temporal scales to form continental and ocean-floor features.
Evaluate evidence of the past and current movements of continental and oceanic crust and the theory of plate tectonics to explain the ages of crustal rocks.
Apply scientific reasoning and evidence from ancient Earth materials, meteorites, and other planetary surfaces to construct an account of Earth’s formation and early history.

Analyze geoscience data and the results from global climate models to make an evidence-based forecast of the current rate of global or regional climate change and associated future impacts to Earth's systems.

english_text: Prokaryote or eukaryote, homeostasis is still an issue for each unicellular organism. A tiny cell in a pond or on the surface of your pencil still needs to find sources of energy or food, to keep concen- trations of water and minerals within certain levels, and to respond quickly to changes in its environment. The microscopic world around us is filled with unicellular organisms that successfully maintain homeostatic balance.
subject: Homeostasis and Cells
spanish_translation: Ya sea procariota o eucariota, la homeostasis sigue siendo un desafío para cada organismo unicelular. Una célula diminuta en un estanque o en la superficie de tu lápiz todavía necesita encontrar fuentes de energía o alimento, mantener las concentraciones de agua y minerales dentro de ciertos niveles y responder rápidamente a los cambios en su entorno. El mundo microscópico que nos rodea está lleno de organismos unicelulares que mantienen exitosamente el equilibrio homeostático.

NGSS_matched_standards.description: Use a model to illustrate the role of cellular division (mitosis) and differentiation in producing and maintaining complex organisms.
Develop and use a model to illustrate the hierarchical organization of interacting systems that provide specific functions within multicellular organisms.

Evaluate claims, evidence, and reasoning that the complex interactions in ecosystems maintain relatively consistent numbers and types of organisms in stable conditions, but changing conditions may result in a new ecosystem.
Use mathematical representations to support claims for the cycling of matter and flow of energy among organisms in an ecosystem.
Plan and conduct an investigation to provide evidence that feedback mechanisms maintain homeostasis.

english_text: Degrees of Longitude: Because a circle is 360 °, the meridian opposite the prime meridian, halfway around the world, is labeled 180 °. All locations east of the prime meridian have longitudes between 0 ° and 180 °E. All locations west of the prime meridian have longitudes between 0 ° and 180 °W. Washington, D.C., which lies west of the prime meridian, has a longitude of 77 °W. Like latitude, longitude can be expressed in degrees, minutes, and seconds. So, a more precise location for Washington, D.C., is 38 °53'23"N, 77 °00'33"W.
subject: Models of the Earth
spanish_translation: Imagina que el mundo es una pelota con 360 líneas imaginarias dibujadas de arriba hacia abajo, como los gajos de una naranja. La línea principal, que es el punto de partida, se llama Meridiano Cero (0°). La línea que está justo al otro lado del mundo es la de 180°. Todos los lugares que están al este del Meridiano Cero tienen números del 0° al 180° Este (E). Y todos los lugares al oeste tienen números del 0° al 180° Oeste (O). Por ejemplo, la ciudad de Washington, D.C. está al oeste de la línea de partida, así que su longitud es 77°O. Para ser súper exactos, los grados se dividen en partes más pequeñas llamadas minutos y segundos. Por eso, la ubicación precisa de Washington, D.C. es 38°53'23"N, 77°00'33"O.

NGSS_matched_standards.description: Develop a model to illustrate how Earth’s internal and surface processes operate at different spatial and temporal scales to form continental and ocean-floor features.

Analyze geoscience data and the results from global climate models to make an evidence-based forecast of the current rate of global or regional climate change and associated future impacts to Earth's systems.
Use a computational representation to illustrate the relationships among Earth systems and how those relationships are being modified due to human activity.
Use mathematical or computational representations to predict the motion of orbiting objects in the solar system.
Analyze geoscience data to make the claim that one change to Earth's surface can create feedbacks that cause changes to other Earth systems.

english_text: Geologic Maps: Geologic maps, such as the one shown in Figure 4, are designed to show the distribution of geologic features. In particular, geo- logic maps show the types of rocks found in a given area and the locations of faults, folds, and other structures. Geologic maps are created on top of another map, called a base map. The base map provides surface features, such as topography or roads, to help identify the location of the geologic units. The base map is commonly printed in light colors or as gray lines so that the geologic information on the map is easy to read and understand.
subject: Models of the Earth
spanish_translation: Mapas Geológicos: Los mapas geológicos, como el ilustrado en la Figura 4, están diseñados para representar la distribución de las formaciones y estructuras geológicas. De manera específica, estos mapas detallan las unidades litológicas que afloran en una región determinada, así como la localización de fallas, pliegues y otras estructuras tectónicas. La cartografía geológica se elabora mediante la superposición de esta información sobre un mapa base, el cual integra rasgos superficiales como la topografía o la red vial para facilitar la georreferenciación precisa de las unidades geológicas. Comúnmente, dicho mapa base se imprime en tonalidades tenues o con un tramado de líneas grises para asegurar que la información geológica superpuesta resalte y sea fácilmente interpretable.

NGSS_matched_standards.description: Develop a model to illustrate how Earth’s internal and surface processes operate at different spatial and temporal scales to form continental and ocean-floor features.
Analyze geoscience data to make the claim that one change to Earth's surface can create feedbacks that cause changes to other Earth systems.
Use a computational representation to illustrate the relationships among Earth systems and how those relationships are being modified due to human activity.
Evaluate evidence of the past and current movements of continental and oceanic crust and the theory of plate tectonics to explain the ages of crustal rocks.

Analyze geoscience data and the results from global climate models to make an evidence-based forecast of the current rate of global or regional climate change and associated future impacts to Earth's systems.

english_text: Geologic Maps: Geologic maps, such as the one shown in Figure 4, are designed to show the distribution of geologic features. In particular, geo- logic maps show the types of rocks found in a given area and the locations of faults, folds, and other structures. Geologic maps are created on top of another map, called a base map. The base map provides surface features, such as topography or roads, to help identify the location of the geologic units. The base map is commonly printed in light colors or as gray lines so that the geologic information on the map is easy to read and understand.
subject: Models of the Earth
spanish_translation: Mapas geológicos: Los mapas geológicos, como el de la Figura 4, muestran la ubicación de las formaciones geológicas. Estos mapas indican los tipos de rocas que hay en un área. También muestran la localización de fallas, pliegues y otras estructuras. Los mapas geológicos se dibujan sobre un mapa base. Este mapa base muestra características de la superficie como la topografía o las carreteras. Esto ayuda a identificar las diferentes unidades rocosas. Usualmente, el mapa base se imprime con colores claros o líneas grises. De esta manera, la información geológica es más fácil de leer y entender.

NGSS_matched_standards.description: Develop a model to illustrate how Earth’s internal and surface processes operate at different spatial and temporal scales to form continental and ocean-floor features.
Analyze geoscience data to make the claim that one change to Earth's surface can create feedbacks that cause changes to other Earth systems.
Use a computational representation to illustrate the relationships among Earth systems and how those relationships are being modified due to human activity.
Evaluate evidence of the past and current movements of continental and oceanic crust and the theory of plate tectonics to explain the ages of crustal rocks.

Analyze geoscience data and the results from global climate models to make an evidence-based forecast of the current rate of global or regional climate change and associated future impacts to Earth's systems.

english_text: Passive Transport Every living cell exists in a liquid environment. One of the most important processes carried out by the cell membrane is to keep a cell in homeostasis. Homeostasis is a state of relatively constant internal physical and chemical conditions. It does this by regulating the movement of molecules and other substances from one side of the membrane to the other side.
subject: Cell Transport
spanish_translation:
Transporte Pasivo
Cada célula viva existe en un ambiente líquido. Uno de los procesos más importantes que realiza la membrana celular es mantener a la célula en homeostasis. La homeostasis es un estado de condiciones físicas y químicas internas relativamente constantes. Esto lo logra regulando el movimiento de moléculas y otras sustancias de un lado de la membrana al otro.

NGSS_matched_standards.description: Use a model to illustrate that cellular respiration is a chemical process whereby the bonds of food molecules and oxygen molecules are broken and the bonds in new compounds are formed, resulting in a net transfer of energy.
Develop and use a model to illustrate the hierarchical organization of interacting systems that provide specific functions within multicellular organisms.
Use a model to illustrate the role of cellular division (mitosis) and differentiation in producing and maintaining complex organisms.
Construct and revise an explanation based on evidence for the cycling of matter and flow of energy in aerobic and anaerobic conditions.
Use mathematical representations to support claims for the cycling of matter and flow of energy among organisms in an ecosystem.

english_text: Types of Maps: Earth scientists use a wide variety of maps that show many dis- tinct characteristics of an area. Some of these characteristics include types of rocks, differences in air pressure, and varying depths of groundwater in a region. Scientists also use maps that show locations, elevations, and surface features of Earth.
subject: Models of the Earth
spanish_translation: Tipos de Mapas: Los científicos de la Tierra utilizan una variedad de mapas que ilustran las características específicas de una región. Algunos mapas muestran los tipos de rocas y las diferencias en la presión del aire, mientras que otros indican las distintas profundidades del agua subterránea. Los científicos también usan mapas, como los topográficos, para señalar ubicaciones, elevaciones y los rasgos de la superficie de la Tierra.

NGSS_matched_standards.description: Develop a model to illustrate how Earth’s internal and surface processes operate at different spatial and temporal scales to form continental and ocean-floor features.
Analyze geoscience data to make the claim that one change to Earth's surface can create feedbacks that cause changes to other Earth systems.
Use a computational representation to illustrate the relationships among Earth systems and how those relationships are being modified due to human activity.

Analyze geoscience data and the results from global climate models to make an evidence-based forecast of the current rate of global or regional climate change and associated future impacts to Earth's systems.
Plan and conduct an investigation of the properties of water and its effects on Earth materials and surface processes.

english_text: Landforms on Topographic Maps: As shown in Figure 3, the spacing and the direction of contour lines indicate the shapes of the landforms represented on a topo- graphic map. Contour lines spaced widely apart indicate that the change in elevation is gradual and that the land is relatively level. Closely spaced contour lines indicate that the change in elevation is rapid and that the slope is steep. A contour line that bends to form a V shape indicates a valley. The bend in the V points toward the higher end of the valley. If a stream or river flows through the valley, the V in the contour line will point upstream, the direction from which the water flows. A river always flows from higher to lower elevation. The width of the V formed by the contour line shows the width of the valley. Contour lines that form closed loops indicate a hilltop or a depression. Generally, a depression is indicated by depression contours, which are closed-loop contour lines that have short, straight lines perpendicular to the inside of the loop. These short lines point toward the center of the depression.
subject: Models of the Earth
spanish_translation: El relieve en los mapas topográficos: El espaciado y la dirección de las curvas de nivel indican el relieve del terreno representado en un mapa topográfico. Las curvas de nivel muy espaciadas señalan que el cambio de elevación es gradual, lo que indica un terreno de pendiente suave. Por el contrario, las curvas de nivel muy juntas indican que el cambio de elevación es rápido y la pendiente es pronunciada. Una curva de nivel que se dobla en forma de V representa un valle; el vértice de la V apunta hacia la zona de mayor elevación del valle. Si un río o arroyo fluye a través del valle, la V en la curva de nivel apuntará aguas arriba, es decir, en la dirección de la que proviene el agua. Un río siempre fluye de una elevación mayor a una menor. La amplitud de la V formada por la curva de nivel muestra la anchura del valle. Las curvas de nivel que forman bucles cerrados indican la cima de una colina o una depresión. Generalmente, una depresión se señaliza con curvas de depresión, que son curvas de nivel cerradas con pequeñas líneas rectas en su interior, perpendiculares al bucle, que apuntan hacia el centro de la depresión.

NGSS_matched_standards.description: Develop a model to illustrate how Earth’s internal and surface processes operate at different spatial and temporal scales to form continental and ocean-floor features.
Use a model to describe how variations in the flow of energy into and out of Earth’s systems result in changes in climate.
Use a computational representation to illustrate the relationships among Earth systems and how those relationships are being modified due to human activity.
Use mathematical representations to support and revise explanations based on evidence about factors affecting biodiversity and populations in ecosystems of different scales.
Use mathematical and/or computational representations to support explanations of factors that affect carrying capacity of ecosystems at different scales.

english_text: Earthquakes and Society: Movement of the ground during an earthquake seldom directly causes many deaths or injuries. Instead, most injuries result from the collapse of buildings and other structures or from falling objects and flying glass. Other dangers include landslides, fires, explosions caused by broken electric and gas lines, and floodwaters released from collapsing dams. Tsunamis: An earthquake whose epicenter is on the ocean floor may cause a giant ocean wave called a tsunami, which may cause serious destruction if it crashes into land. A tsunami may begin to form when a sudden drop or rise in the ocean floor occurs because of faulting associated with undersea earthquakes. The drop or rise of the ocean floor causes a large mass of sea water to also drop or rise suddenly. This movement sets into motion a series of long, low waves that increase in height as they near the shore. These waves are tsunamis.
subject: Earthquakes
spanish_translation:
En un terremoto, la tierra se mueve. Moverse no es lo que lastima a la gente. Lo peligroso es cuando las casas se caen. También cuando los objetos nos caen encima. A veces, el temblor puede causar incendios.

Los terremotos también pueden pasar en el fondo del mar. Esto puede crear una ola gigante. Se llama tsunami. El piso del mar se mueve de repente. Empuja el agua con mucha fuerza. Así nace una ola enorme. La ola se hace más y más alta cerca de la tierra. Un tsunami es muy peligroso.

NGSS_matched_standards.description: Develop a model to illustrate how Earth’s internal and surface processes operate at different spatial and temporal scales to form continental and ocean-floor features.
Analyze geoscience data to make the claim that one change to Earth's surface can create feedbacks that cause changes to other Earth systems.
Evaluate evidence of the past and current movements of continental and oceanic crust and the theory of plate tectonics to explain the ages of crustal rocks.
Construct an explanation based on evidence for how the availability of natural resources, occurrence of natural hazards, and changes in climate have influenced human activity.
Plan and conduct an investigation of the properties of water and its effects on Earth materials and surface processes.

english_text: Transmission Electron Microscopes: These microscopes make it possible to explore cell structures and large protein molecules. Beams of electrons can only pass through thin samples, so cells and tissues must be cut into extremely thin slices before they can be examined. This is the reason that such images often appear flat and two dimensional.
subject: Life is Cellular
spanish_translation: Microscopios Electrónicos de Transmisión: Estos microscopios permiten analizar en detalle tanto la ultraestructura celular como las macromoléculas proteicas. Debido a que los haces de electrones solo pueden penetrar muestras sumamente delgadas, es un requisito indispensable que las células y los tejidos sean seccionados en cortes ultrafinos antes de su examinación. Esta limitación inherente al procedimiento explica por qué las imágenes resultantes presentan una apariencia plana y bidimensional.

NGSS_matched_standards.description: Plan and conduct an investigation to gather evidence to compare the structure of substances at the bulk scale to infer the strength of electrical forces between particles.
Communicate scientific and technical information about why the molecular-level structure is important in the functioning of designed materials.
Communicate technical information about how some technological devices use the principles of wave behavior and wave interactions with matter to transmit and capture information and energy.
Construct an explanation based on evidence for how the structure of DNA determines the structure of proteins, which carry out the essential functions of life through systems of specialized cells.
Apply science and engineering ideas to design, evaluate, and refine a device that minimizes the force on a macroscopic object during a collision.

english_text: Physical Stability of Rocks: Rocks have natural zones of weakness that are deter- mined by how and where the rocks form. For example, sedimentary rocks may form as a series of layers of sediment. These rocks tend to break between layers. Some metamorphic rocks also tend to break in layers that form as the minerals in the rocks align during metamorphism. Massive igneous rock structures commonly have evenly spaced zones of weakness, called joints, that form as the rock cools and contracts. Devils Postpile, shown in Figure 4, is igneous rock that has joints that cause the rock to break into columns. Zones of weakness may also form when the rock is under intense pressure inside Earth. When rock that formed under intense pressure is uplifted to Earth’s surface, decreased pressure allows the joints and fractures to open. Once these weaknesses are exposed to air and water, chemical and physical processes begin to break down the rock.
subject: Rocks
spanish_translation: Las rocas tienen puntos débiles naturales que dependen de cómo y dónde se formaron. Por ejemplo, las rocas sedimentarias se forman con muchas capas de materiales. Estas rocas suelen romperse entre esas capas. Algunas rocas metamórficas también se parten en capas, que se forman cuando los minerales de la roca se ordenan en filas mientras la roca se transforma. Las grandes rocas ígneas a menudo tienen zonas débiles, como grietas, que aparecen a la misma distancia unas de otras. Estas grietas se forman cuando la roca se enfría y se encoge. Un ejemplo famoso es una roca ígnea con grietas que hacen que se parta en forma de columnas. Los puntos débiles también pueden formarse cuando la roca está bajo una presión muy fuerte dentro de la Tierra. Cuando esa roca sube a la superficie, la presión disminuye, lo que permite que las grietas y fracturas se abran. Una vez que estos puntos débiles quedan en contacto con el aire y el agua, distintos procesos químicos y físicos empiezan a romper la roca.

NGSS_matched_standards.description: Develop a model to illustrate how Earth’s internal and surface processes operate at different spatial and temporal scales to form continental and ocean-floor features.
Apply scientific reasoning and evidence from ancient Earth materials, meteorites, and other planetary surfaces to construct an account of Earth’s formation and early history.
Evaluate evidence of the past and current movements of continental and oceanic crust and the theory of plate tectonics to explain the ages of crustal rocks.
Analyze geoscience data to make the claim that one change to Earth's surface can create feedbacks that cause changes to other Earth systems.
Communicate scientific and technical information about why the molecular-level structure is important in the functioning of designed materials.

english_text: The Discovery of the Cell: “Seeing is believing” goes an old saying. It would be hard to find a better example of this than the discovery of the cell. Without the instruments to make them visible, cells remained unknown for most of human history. All of this changed with a dramatic advance in technology—the invention of the microscope.
subject: Life is Cellular
spanish_translation: El Hallazgo de la Célula: “Ver para creer” dice un viejo dicho. Es difícil encontrar un mejor ejemplo que esto y el hallazgo de la célula. Sin instrumentos para verlas, las células eran desconocidas. Todo cambió cuando se hizo el microscopio.

NGSS_matched_standards.description: Use a model to illustrate the role of cellular division (mitosis) and differentiation in producing and maintaining complex organisms.
Plan and conduct an investigation to provide evidence that an electric current can produce a magnetic field and that a changing magnetic field can produce an electric current.
Communicate scientific ideas about the way stars, over their life cycle, produce elements.
Apply scientific reasoning and evidence from ancient Earth materials, meteorites, and other planetary surfaces to construct an account of Earth’s formation and early history.
Construct an explanation based on evidence for how the structure of DNA determines the structure of proteins, which carry out the essential functions of life through systems of specialized cells.

english_text: Electrons are easily scattered by molecules in the air, which means samples must be placed in a vacuum to be studied with an electron microscope. As a result, researchers must chemically preserve their samples. This means that electron microscopy, despite its higher resolution, can be used to examine only nonliving cells and tis- sues. The two major types of electron microscopes are transmission and scanning.
subject: Life is Cellular
spanish_translation: Las partes pequeñas se mueven por el aire. Las muestras están en un espacio sin aire. Los científicos cuidan bien las muestras. La lupa poderosa solo ve cosas no vivas. Hay dos tipos de lupas. Uno es para ver a través. El otro es para ver en seguida.

NGSS_matched_standards.description: Plan and conduct an investigation to gather evidence to compare the structure of substances at the bulk scale to infer the strength of electrical forces between particles.
